number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												6.5/10. I had much higher hopes for this game, and was definitely disappointed by the game, but it's still not a bad game. I was hoping for a game with mystery, atmopshere, adventure, excitement, horror, paranormal, etc. This game was less than I expected. You basically spend the game walking around solving puzzles and searching giant environments for a few objects, just like other adventure games. There is really no player interaction and really any action at all. There is 1 tense/scary part and that is about it. The game feels quite empty. I did love the atmosphere. The visuals and feel of the area are some of the best I have ever seen, and this game was made for screenshots. The areas are varied and the graphics are decent. The crime solving can be fun sometimes with observations made by your character. Sometimes solving the order of events and finding objects can feel intuitive and you enjoy it. Other times the scenes used for the order involve a person standing there by themselves, or 1 scene has a new person none of the others do, and since it's just a still you cannot possibly gain an idea of what happened enough to put things in order. The game does this with clues. Sometimes you have to wonder off in a tiny area to find something. Like adventure games, if you don't find all the puzzles, and every object/clue and trigger every event, you can't beat the game. This means you'll prolly use a walkthrough, because of how big and open environements are, and there is no help from the game at all. The game says it doesn't "hold your hand" but in reality they are just being obtuse and  poor with some object placement and scene solving just to make it harder for no reason. The game is short. The story is interesting to begin with and you are invested in what happens, and without spoiling anything, the ending is kind of a dud. So the best part of the game is the environment and visuals, with some interest from the story. The gameplay is the same ol boring item find/puzzle solve of an adventure game, with walkthrough needing for some parts, but does have a few new novel mechanics to use.

Posted: March 2, 2015
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a beautifuly designed masterpiece.The very moment you open your eyes, the game absolutely stuns with beautiful visuals and as you are gently walking your first steps in the world, you will immidiately feel that childish sense of wonder and excitement, but that is only the beginning of the beautifu and sad experience that awaits you. The story is told in a slow pace and you have more than enough time to enjjoy the beautiful scenery. The game is surprisingly not linear yet for most part, you wont find yourself aimlessly wandering. As the story slowly unfolds, you are more and more intrigued by the question how did this happen ?As you finish the game, the ending will just hit you like a freight train. Absolutely unexpected not even by hardcore book readers / movie fans or gamers. Even tough I have to say that the storytelling in this game is more subtle and wont get into your bones as much a for example Brothers: Tale of two sons the game makes up for it fully with its stunning visuals, unique game mechanics and beautiful Norwegian like setting.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter tells several stories tied by a single main narrative in an engaging and visually atractive way.The graphics are very good, the music is up to scratch and mirrors the mood of the various places visited throughout the game. I think the main downside of this title is how short the gameplay is. It took me just three hours to discover and complete all of the available stories and puzzles, as well as all but one achievement.If anyone's looking for an adventure game, like those of the Myst series, including Uru, you might find the puzzles not challenging enough, maybe even disappointing. However,  The Vanishing of Ethan Carter simply does not belong to this genre. It's more of a multimedia story. Not an adventure game, not a pure story like Dear Esther, but something inbetween.It's probably not a game I'm ever going to replay but I certainly concider it money well-spent. Playing through it felt like reading a book (and a decent one) in many ways. The most vibrant inspiration behind the storyline seems to be that drawn from the works of H. P. Lovecraft. However, subtle hints of the styles and interests represented by multiple other authors can be picked up by an attentive player.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an exceedingly beautiful game visually, a surprising and ultimately very sad game narratively.Gameplay-wise, the focus is exploration. It walks the line between being a walking simulator, a hidden objects game and (thanks due to a few simple, yet engaging puzzles) a classic point-and-click adventure. It's an engaging mix, especially due to the absolutely excellent score and aforementioned visuals; and you truly feel a bit like a detective as you investigate the game world.I can't think of a way to say more about the game without spoiling it or without becoming too subjective. Honestly, the official game description says plenty. I think if based on that and the screenshots you think the game would appeal to you; then there's a very good chance it will. It definitely was the case for me - I had a wonderful time exploring, and the story ended up personally resonating with me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This game...This game blew my mind. Mysterious discovery adventure powered by unreal engine with graphics so outstanding you will never have to go out again, you can have your own forest at home on your monitor.Despite textures detailed to the latest pixel the game runs like a clockwork even on my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• laptop on HD resolution. Sure it lags for a second or two now and then (especially between another map segments) but that is no big issue especially if the game has no loading screens.The story is not as original as it seems, on the other hand it will surprise you as nothing is as it seems.The gameplay itself is interesting. First, as autors stated, game does not hold your hand. You have no idea what to do or hwere to go and it is all up to you to explore and find out. Due to a fact you cannot die in this game (or... can you? ok you can at one and only one segment of the game, beware da jumpscare!!) you can literally explore everything. There are invisible wall and small rocks or logs you cannot jump across but map is HUGE. Huge enough for you to have a lot of space to explore anyway.It might take you a while to realize and understand what game wants from you. How to use supernatural abilities of main protagonist and progress in the game.Eventually you make it to the end after just few hours of gameplay. You might get lost on the way, you will get lost. You will explore a lot, run around with no clue where to go next but it is allrigh, because the game looks gorgeous!The music is awesome. Fits to the setting, with its melancholy theme.I am not fun of these games, or at least I was not but now that I played this and few similar games (like Kholat) I am changing my mind.This is one job well done. I can only recommend this unique experience.

												I don't usually write reviews on games, but I thought I needed to write one for this one. Even though the game is short (I finished it in 5.5 hours) I would most definitely recommend getting it if it's on sale. The story of this game is amazing, you never now what to expect. Even though at times seems horror like, the games objective is to let you take your time in solving the mysteries. There is never a time limit or any enemies that kill you, all you have to worry about is solving them. My biggest mistake is rushing through the game from the beginning. If you take your time and look around the world, you will have a better gaming experience. This game is definitely worth playing.

												Amazing graphics (ran smoothly with max. settings on Nvidia GeForce GTX 960M) and perfect soundtrack - this game is really immersive and if I had an Oculus Rift I would really love to try it with this game. I played this in ~6.5hrs without trying to break any speed records... which might be considered short regarding the price. It took me while to fully understand the main characters special ability and how to use it - not sure if it was just me being too stupid or if a little tutorial in the beginning would be called for.I liked the puzzles which I think could be a bit more complex - but on the other hand more straight forward puzzles can avoid a lot of frustration for the players and difficulty is a very subjective thing...The story is great and in the end everything suddenly made some sense - even though a lot of players won't like the ending.If there was a sequel - I'd get it immediately. (9/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a very mysterious adventure game in an absolutely stunning environment. You are a detective who is to find a boy who has been missing. This game does not have a lot of game to it, and is very much a narrative focused experience, which I'm a huge fan of. The music really sets the tone together with the very high quality graphics and beautiful, well-crafted environments with immense mountains and lush forests. I especially liked the timing of the music, which really set the tone just right for every part of the world.By solving puzzles you unravel a series of very mysterious and macabre tales in the world. The puzzles aren't very difficult, but finding out what the puzzle actually is is a lot more challenging. I somehow managed to skip the first 2 puzzles and just walked straight by them, only to complete them at the end. I was simply not aware of the fact that those were puzzles. The game can feel a bit pretentious with its whole "not holding hands" at times, and can scare away newcomers to games.Other criticism I have is that, while the story is nicely told, it's not in every part of it. The character art, voice over and development really pales compared to the setting making it very hard to empathise with them. Furthermore, there are some very cheap jumpscares in the game that I thought were utterly unnecessary, and in adventure games I nearly always find inexcusable. In the end the story itself also doesn't have much of a lasting appeal even when so masterfully told, which is a problem I have with most of the games in the genre. It's however probably still my favourite game of 2014, and a huge recommendation.I'm feeling a light to a decent 8.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												This game tells a story. It tells it very well--incredibly well. Some people have complained about its length. I say that it is more than twice as long as most movies, and more in depth as well. Because of the interactive elements, this game tells the story far better than any movie could. Do i wish it were longer? yes, I do. Am I still satisfied with the product? Very much yes.Visuals 10/10Incredible, not just in quality but in design.Sound 9/10Great sounds, great music. very immersive. there were a couple of audio glitches though, and it wouldn't work with my surround sound.Story 9/10 Great story. Well presented. Short.Gameplay 8/10This game reminded me of old school point and clicks, but in 3D with much more polish. Being a hybrid of a first person game and a point and click, I felt elements of both missing though. Like the lack of any way to jump (would serve no purpose really, just didn't feel natural without it) and lack of a viewable inventory or map. However, these things didn't really detract from the gameplay, and the lack of them almost added to the game's style.Would I recommend you get this game? Do you like story and puzzles? Then yes, get this game (maybe on sale, its only 5-6 hours long). If not, leave it be. If you are here for the horror alone, you might be disapointed. The game definately had a creepy atmosphere, a fair share of disturbing scenes, and a handfull of "horror" scenes--but not enough for me to really call this a horror game.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an exceedingly beautiful game visually, a surprising and ultimately very sad game narratively.Gameplay-wise, the focus is exploration. It walks the line between being a walking simulator, a hidden objects game and (thanks due to a few simple, yet engaging puzzles) a classic point-and-click adventure. It's an engaging mix, especially due to the absolutely excellent score and aforementioned visuals; and you truly feel a bit like a detective as you investigate the game world.I can't think of a way to say more about the game without spoiling it or without becoming too subjective. Honestly, the official game description says plenty. I think if based on that and the screenshots you think the game would appeal to you; then there's a very good chance it will. It definitely was the case for me - I had a wonderful time exploring, and the story ended up personally resonating with me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												A beautiful game, excellent storytelling, and, with a couple of caveats, an immersive experience.  The game will take between 4 and 6 hours to fully complete, depending on how much you backtrack.  If you let the game guide you a little, it's a fairly linear experience, but otherwise it's open for exploration.A few caveats before diving in, some of them kind of important to consider when playing the game:1.) This game can cause Simulation Sickness in those who are sensitive.  I fall amongst those, and despite tinkering in the settings to change the view angle and such, I still got very ill playing this game.  That didn't stop me from playing, but it did force me to only an hour or two of playing before I had to take a break and sleep the sickness off.  Your mileage may vary.2.) The save system is not player-controlled.  Instead, it saves after (and sometimes before) important scenes.  Because of this, you can find yourself having to re-tread old territory if you were exploring quite a bit and didn't encounter a scene save.  However, if you re-play a scene or re-read a story, the scene will save again, so you can use these scenes as waypoints.  It's not the "conventional" way to save, so this may throw some people off, but it really isn't that big a deal.3.) Certain game mechanics that you would expect from a first-person perspective game are missing.  Primarily, the ability to jump.  There are run and crouch mechanics, but sometimes you just want to climb over a rock and jump to try to... only for nothing to happen.  Not really a big deal, since there isn't anything there (that's the game's way of saying, "Turn back") but it's another of those minor hitches that can trip a player up.In essence, this is a game a little bit like Dear Esther, with the "games as storytelling device" mechanics, but I feel it does so in fine form.  Their spin on psychic investigation is quite novel, the effects very cool, and overall the whole game just compelled me to want to keep going.  Take your time when playing so you can really take it all in, from the scenery to the cutscenes to the narration.If $20 is a little steep for you, wait for it to go on sale, but at the very least put it in your Wishlist so you'll be notified when it does.  Oh, and maybe take a Dramamine once you get started.Highly recommended, and I hope to see more such stories from these developers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												My favorite author is H.P. Lovecraft, so I make a point of checking out every game or movie that claims to be inspired by his work.  Usually the end result is pretty weak sauce, but sometimes I find epic experiences like Eternal Darkness or Dark Corners of the Earth ... or shorter, but still powerful stories like Ethan Carter.The game's story is more in line with Lovecraft's early work, with the focus on internalized existential angst with a smattering of references to the wider mythos and the power of dreams.  It's a slower, more personal, self-contained story, rather than one about ancient aliens rising up from terrible slumber to end humanity, which is fine.  Gameplay is all about investigating a series of murders in the gorgeously rendered Red Creek Valley while searching for Ethan Carter.  There is no combat and no way to die (although there is a gamebreaking bug that I at first mistook for character death towards the end, if you solve one of the puzzles before the final murder, that requires you to close the game and continue from the previous save).The unique method of sensing the psychic residue of strong emotions and reconstructing the timelines of the murders is clever and provides the only real "action" to what is primarily a short story you get to walk through and witness.  There are no outcomes to change, no secret endings, no agency for you as a player at all, really, other than the order in which you solve the murders.Graphically, the game is beautiful, alternating between peaceful and creepy, as needed.  The environments look and sound real and are the key to the experience.  Lesser visuals would have hurt the immersion.  The character models are less impressive by comparison, but the voice acting makes up for that and provides some believable personalities.  I would recommend you disable Motion Blur in the Graphics options, as I found it nauseating and a distraction from the great artwork done for the game.Total game time, exploring every possible location is 4-5 hrs, and for an $8 game, I can't really complain.  I pay more than that to see a 2 hr movie at the theatre.  Replayability is practically nil, however.  Once you have solved a murder or puzzle the hard way (without a guide - using one will only hurt your experience in the long run), you can easily burn through it again without much effort, further cutting down the game time to less than 2 hrs, easily, accounting for walking time and watching the cutscenes.  You'd be better off introducing someone else to the game, rather than play through it multiple times.  Then you could discuss the ending!For an additional $4, you can get a digital map, poster, making of document, and the origianl soundtrack, which I purchased to support the developers and found worth it for the great atmospheric music alone.If you want to experience a beautiful visual tale of mystery and the occult in the vein of H.P. Lovecraft, there's hardly a better way to spend a lazy afternoon.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Technical:Doesn't support 21:9 or wider screen resolutions. Flawlesswidescreen fixes thisBuilt on the Unreal Engine, so performance is amazing and the graphics are breathtakingSeriously, buy the game, if only to bask in the gloriousness of the PC Master RaceMy thoughts:Masterpiece. Absolutely incredible at building an environment to play in.Little bit of a learning curve though. This game is a bit...different to play, than any other game I've played before. A lot of weird things go on, that can sometimes creep you out. Don't let your common sense grab hold of you, this is more along the lines of The Twilight Zone. Think of this title as a supernatural Nancy Drew, the the visual fidelity of Crysis, and the ability to tell a story on the level of Metro 2033. Stellar game, very much a 'proof of concept though'. Relatively short, you could beat this game in 4 hours if you tried. Although, it does take some getting used to.My final thoughts on the story of the game: Creations through observation.(Get it on sale though $10 is a reasonable price point I'd say)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												'The Vanishing of Ethan Carter' can aptly be described as a horror-puzzle game.  However, this label is slightly deceptive.  The game does not contain the B-movie scares of a 'Resident Evil' or the psychological terror of a 'Silent Hill'.  Instead it possesses a heavy atmosphere and a thick sense of dread.You play as Paul Prospero, a noir detective investigating the disappearance of Ethan Carter.  This investigation takes you to the seemingly abandoned woodland environs where the Carter family once lived.  As you retrace Ethan's steps, you use your skills to reconstruct murder scenes that slowly link together to form a greater story, one that begins with Ethan's accidental awakening of a creature known only as the 'sleeper', and which continues into greater violence and madness.Although the world seems quite big, it is actually quite linear.  There are ten puzzles total.  Half involve investigating the aforementioned crimes by recreating murder scenes in order to understand the chronology of the death.  The other half relate to Ethan's short fictions, which he writes with a lonely heart.  These puzzles seemingly have no connection to the main game, but...From an empirical point of view, 'The Vanishing of Ethan Carter' does not contain much content; I played through it in three hours.  But having bought it during a Steam sale, I will say that it feels well worth the money I spent.  It is a heartbreaking story that filled me with uneasiness and mystery, and left me oddly pensive in the end.-----------------------I wrote my storiesFor you to read; but alsoTo save my own soul.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Great game! Very moody, beautiful graphics, beautiful music, great voice from the player character and an interesting world and puzzles that makes sense.It took me 4h to complete it, would probably have taken shorter if they had actually explained how a feature worked, there are no tutorials because 90% of the game doesn't need one. Shame though that the main mechanic thats used really could have done with SOME explanation. Anyway, heres my explanation for it: When you see the cloud of words, look around until they are focused into one word. You will probably understand if you read this sentence when you're ingame. :)Its a mystery adventure in first person where you investigate, explore and try and sequence together what happened to make the world end up as it did before you arrived. As such it is very slow, there is no action in it whatsoever, you are there as an observer, investigator and solver. As such you cannot die or fail, however you might end up having an area reset or force you to the beginning of the puzzle.Graphics: Environments are amazing, it looks extremely good and everything just feels correct, which is good since its 95% of the things that you will look at. This is exactly how I expect Half Life 3 forests to look at, it feels like being back in the forests from Episode 2, but just amazing looking. Characters are probably the weakest point, they look lackluster next to the environment.Sound: Great great music, reminds me of skyrim, beautiful and calm. Voice acting was ok, the player character is clearly the best, would like to have heard more from him. Only iffy about the sound is that the 3d positioning were at times really bad. In one area I had to stand in the middle of the room to hear the ghostly voices at a correct level, and in another place I couldn't position the enormous water source because the sound didn't come from a specific direction. Minor things but kind of odd when playing with headphones.Technical things: Worked great on my computer, no crashes or anything. Had some annoying stuttering when I moved around and new assets loaded, otherwise the performance was fine on my 780ti. Might just be my SSD that is kind of bad, not a new thing for me.Only encountered one bug that forced me to reload to the latest autosave, kind of annoying but didn't happen anywhere else.If you feel that 20‚Ç¨ for 4 hours is a bit short you will be missing out on a beautiful game. I really enjoyed it and hope you will too, and that there will come more short games like these.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												You should know what you're getting into here. It's a game based on story and exploration. No action, minimal puzzles. As long as that doesn't completely put you off the whole idea, then definitely give this a try. It's eerie, subtle horror at its finest- no jump scares, no looming theat (except for one very brief, easy to beat segment). And yet the game left me deeply chilled, and more than a little bit sad.But if you play, have a guide on hand. Not because the puzzles are hard (they're not), but because some things are easy to miss- and you have to solve every puzzle in order to complete the game. If you don't want to spend an hour backtracking to that one spot you missed, check the guide every so often to make sure you haven't skipped anything. No need to read ahead or spoil things for yourself- just read up to the point you reached and see if there's anything you should have done.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
 Review Time!!!!       So ill first start out with my original thought of game pre purchase.  I like all sorts of games so long as they bring something to the table that intrigues me.  In this case i had watched the trailer and the gameplay videos on steam, and decided that this game had first off amazing visuals (not just graphically but landscape design was pretty great)  and a style of game play that just struck me as a refreshing change of pace to my growing stack of story driven/puzzle games.  I had discussed the gameplay to my friend, (as we went upon an expedition into the forest to chop trees for quickly arriving winter) then nothing. I guess along the journey I had expressed interest in the purchase of the game, but only whence my financial portfolio was performing better. Fast forward a time we are cutting more wood we arrive back at the casa and i have a steam message.  Turns out whilst i was preoccupied my friend had found time to purchase the game without me knowing, and left me a message  We should play the game upon its download and then something about drinking yada yada  twas a great message.     Game installs we click play and the pre game window launches.  I enjoy when a game does this.  Not only does it remind me about changing the graphics settings, but makes the whole process much easier especially if the game is like Fable Anniversary and has the worst computer interface i have ever had the misfortune of dealing with.  After a few moments of turning everything to  maximum overdrive  it was finally time to play.  The Games Main Menu was very simple nice scenery of a meadow i believe now that i think about it i cant really remember, but i do remember a tree in the bottom left corner. There were four or so options we clicked new game or whatever it is to begin our adventure into saving some small child in a basement from his moth.... oh wait thats the  Binding of Isaac  .... to save a boy whom has vanished.     The game opens into an amazing graphically vivid environment.  Slight nuissance of blurring around the non focused center area of screen, but its an attempt to be more realistic i guess.  Controls are very simple which is good because there is no tutorial.  Straight into  Murder Train  mystery solving.  The solving of events is pretty simple; find dead guy, restore crime scene, and use dead guy's memories (I personally think that Paul Prospero is Dumbledore in disguise hence the use of pensieve) to discover a series of events that you must piece together to gain access to the dead spirits last major memory as its soul is torn from the world of the living.   BOOM  Solved my first scene psychic powers FTW.  Thus far into the game about 15 minutes or so, and the daunting question begins to arrive  "How long is this game?"  This question never popped into my mind before, but story driven games are notorious for being rather short. I personally am ok with a game thats a few hours of great story because hey its a genre with usually a better story than an fps, but without the  pchew pchew.   Although at this  point you are also wondering is there going to be a good storyline as well. All you know is  there is an entity named the  Sleeper  controlling people. Ethan is resistant to its call, and he is in trouble.      That is it for giveaways to the story and progress that takes place now its the moment everyones been waiting for.  My friend and i finished the game it roughly 2 hours and 30 minutes.  Thats full completion all miscellaneous events and all story driven ones.  The story had its share of depth, but id say most of the depth came from the miscellaneous events and tidbits of  Ethan's  stories.  Twice were we caught off guard by sudden bouts of quiet to super loud doubtfully intentional jump scares.... Ok maybe one was intentional, and it got us because here we are joking about  should we run..... no he disappeared OHHH SH** . Anywho it was fun.  The ending was in my personal oppinion lack luster with everything you gather through out the story you start to see whats up.  Atleast we did.  As for exact events we didn't have that figured and it made for an interesting addition but we both felt strange about it.     Still no regrets from either of us about the $20 dollar price tag, and those whom complain that they just spent $5 bucks per hour of enjoyment we spent $10 and i will say $10 bucks per hour for a great time and pleasure of playing this game is worth it to keep this group of developers making games.  My suggestion is buy it call a friend have him pick up a six pack of a nice lager, and play the game. If you know someone who has this game call em up plan a day to drink and play it and just enjoy the time.  Maybe they themselves are regretting the purchase buy the beer and say hey now you've gotten some money back, (at this point they wont care because they have now officially enjoyed the game for a second playthrough) and you will have solved  The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												This game creeps and puts you on edge without anything campy or over the top. The game does a great job developing an unease, making the player feel as if they are a tresspasser in a land where things just are not quite right. The graphics and sound are beautiful bringing to life ancient forests, dilapidated structures, and artifacts of industry gone by the wayside. I really enjoyed wandering the map. Which you will have to, because there isn't a lot that is intuitive about "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter." Players who enjoyed the old "Myst" series will find some nostalgia here, but the puzzles are not as deep, and often, knowing whether you are in the puzzle is half the puzzle.  Once you solve your first major puzzle you will discover the pattern they take, but too often, the missing piece I needed to solve something was obscure, or worse, something I considered but just didn't do in the right order.Never the less, I enjoyed "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter." I recommend it with a little hesitation, as it isn't for everyone.

												The world's visual glory might cloud the story but the unadorned gameplay steers narration with a clear focus and little regard to the player's ability to trail it. Pieces don't fall in place until the end, and the outcome might leave the player emotionally unrewarded. Nonetheless it compresses the game's themes into a satisfying whole.The story's hopefulness is its love letter to literature. It's the celebration of imagination and the naivistic nod to those who have tried to escape desolation in a dysfunctional family. It's the absence of absolute evil; Sleeper's function is not to frighten, it is to reflect our innermost needs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												The game says it like it is as soon as you begin the story.  It doesn't hold your hand.  Nothing is "obvious" in regards to path or connections to the story.  You have to earn it by exploring and acting the detective that you are.  That means combing the woods, paths, buildings, or whatever you can see.  Most of the clues are fairly close together to one another, but there are some that are not.  You will not know until you explore every place that you are physically able to.  I love this sort of game because it is rare in today's gaming culture.  The masses play games now and the masses want simplicity.  This game is not simple.  It will frusterate you at times because you will not know what your next move is.  Youtube tutorials will be a constant temptation, but I urge you to only use them when you absolutly have to.  Discovering and figuring out things on your own is what motivates you to go on.  The story is well thought out, but there isn't a lot of dialogue that will help you along the way.  If this game was to have come out on consoles it'd be worth the normal $60 price tag, so you know its a steal for $20.  It's a memorable game that will hopefully influence a genre that will be improved upon even more than this game presents.  Give it a try if you want a challenging story that encourages exploring.  If you think that sounds boring, this game is not for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												I've just played this through and I loved every minute.This is an open world puzzle game with an intriguing mystery storyline with horror elements. You take the role of a detective investigating the titular disappearance of a young boy, Ethan Carter. It's pretty hard to discuss the narrative further without giving away spoilers. It has been described as Lovecraftian, I would say there are a few nods to Lovecraft and the Cthulhu Mythos, but it's not the basis of the whole story.The puzzles are logical and not too tough to solve once you understand the mechanic. I did feel that the later murders were a little easier to solve and felt like less work had been put into them compared to say the first one. The puzzles are not all the same though, and there is a good variety to keep the player interested. I would suggest avoiding checking walkthroughs or guides as the puzzles are all achievable with a bit of thought. The graphics are stunning, the level of detail is very high and it must have taken a huge amount of work to create the game world. Pretty much everywhere you look there are amazing views and the landscape is very serene and peaceful. There is a known issue of flashing red lights in the trees which affects Radeon cards, and I did observe it but it wasn't frequent enough to cause a distraction.A few people have complained about the length of this game. You can expect 5-7 hours of gameplay depending on how good you are at solving the puzzles. I personally think that is pretty reasonable. I'd much rather have 6 hours of quality gameplay than 12 hours of filler.Anyway, I'm definitely recommending this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great example of what a game can be based on nothing but environment and story elements. It uses far-reaching landscapes and beautiful visual effects to bring you a great narrative experience. However, be warned, this game may not be for those of little patience.__________Synopsis:You play as Paul Prospero, who seems to be a detective with paranormal abilities such as ESP. Receiving a letter from Ethan Carter, he learns Ethan has strong psychic connections, and that he has gone missing. Your job is to explore the village of Red Creek Valley and find Ethan. You quickly learn that something is amiss; the town is abandoned, no sign of Ethan's family, and mysterious occurrences. Story: A short, but interesting tale shrouded in mystery. Perhaps too short, depending on how quickly you progress through the game. It doesn't suffer very much from ups and downs in the story, and it ends pretty well too. Graphics: One of the most visually appealing games I've played in a long time. A wider, open world gives you plenty of room to stretch your legs and explore, taking in the sights and sounds as you go along. Functionality: Controls are pretty linear and simple. Essentially a Sherlock Holmes-puzzle solving game. Pick stuff up, find where it goes, and solve problems. Gameplay: Overall, it's not good. Again, it's basically a point-and-click mystery game akin to Sherlock Holmes. There is no combat mechanics, and every item falls into the one-use category. The real problem I encountered was spending obnoxiously long amounts of time searching the vast landscape for potential clues, which a majority of them felt arbitrary. This is where those of little patience may find the game frustrating.______________________________At the end of the day, you're buying this game for the story and the experience; but the experience tends to fall short when you're slowly crawling over a couple acres of land looking for that one last piece of the puzzle. I feel this may have been a better release under a different venue, like Heavy Rain, which offers great atmosphere, narritive, and incorporates at least DECENT gameplay elements. I did enjoy it, but my advice would be to wait until this game goes on sale to purchase.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												You should know what you're getting into here. It's a game based on story and exploration. No action, minimal puzzles. As long as that doesn't completely put you off the whole idea, then definitely give this a try. It's eerie, subtle horror at its finest- no jump scares, no looming theat (except for one very brief, easy to beat segment). And yet the game left me deeply chilled, and more than a little bit sad.But if you play, have a guide on hand. Not because the puzzles are hard (they're not), but because some things are easy to miss- and you have to solve every puzzle in order to complete the game. If you don't want to spend an hour backtracking to that one spot you missed, check the guide every so often to make sure you haven't skipped anything. No need to read ahead or spoil things for yourself- just read up to the point you reached and see if there's anything you should have done.

												I had really looked forward to this game: the visuals, the gameplay and the type of "puzzle adventure".The graphics are amazing! It's like walking in a real forest and in a real "town". This, in combination with great music, makes you as a player feel as an active part of the story and you can feel that there is something cooking under the surface. Other games have to tell you that there is something going one, this game makes you feel it!Without spoiling it, the story is a bit weak at times and the story falls flat in the end. This could be, due to my inability to play it in on sitting, however, the end could have been a bit more explanatory and give the player a deeper understanding of the reasoning behind the story.But, the question is, should you buy and play this game? Yes, if you're into the genre of "adventure puzzle" and like a good story combined with some good puzzles. Or just buy it if you never have experienced a nordic forest and would like to know how amazing it can look during fall.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
A Paladin‚Äôs Steam Review: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. A Subtly Disturbing Yet Compelling Mystery Game.Genre: First Person Atmospheric Story Driven Mystery with Psychological Horror ElementsDeveloper & Publisher: The AstronautsPlatform Support: Windows, PS4. Mac & Linux "Coming Soon". Business Model: Base Game. Copy Purchased by MyselfOverall Gameplay ThoughtsVanishing comes very, very close to a Walking Simulator. There really isn‚Äôt a failure state, your actions don‚Äôt really affect the game in any meaningful way and the game expects you to experience a lot of it. The only influence you have is exploring the world of Red Creek Valley, solving the puzzles and, by extension, the mystery Paul Prospero is here to solve. Oh right, that‚Äôs the guy who you‚Äôre controlling and hear monologue as you explore the valley. So, you'll walk along at a fairly steady pace (there's a reasonably faster sprint as well), drink in the atmosphere while you search for clues of Ethan's whereabouts. All the while discovering that there's something creepy and sinister beneath the surface. Red Creek Valley is divided up into multiple areas, each containing a major puzzle or two for you to solve. Puzzles, for the most part, boil down to finding all the objects within a given area and figuring out how they all go together. The music playing in the background will clue you in on whether you‚Äôve left the given area very subtly. Which is helpful because you‚Äôll never need to leave an area in order to solve that particular puzzle. There aren‚Äôt any random items on the other side of the map that you have to find. It should be noted that it isn't required to solve these puzzle areas in any particular order, they can be done at any time. Outside of soaking in the sights and experiencing the strange events going on, there‚Äôs not much else to do. However, I always felt like I was involved. There wasn't any boring section I felt forced to walk through. It might help that Red Creek Valley appealed to me. Being able to see the burned out buildings, the rusted train cars and nature reclaiming the area, it really intrigued me. It's a feel of history and decay that Vanishing goes out of its way to really sell to the player. It feels like a real place and it‚Äôs setup like a real place. I think that helped me enjoy the game more. Atmosphere & JumpscaresThe atmosphere ate away at me. Slowly, creepily, I would sometimes jump at my phone beeping at me. It‚Äôs insidious how this game gets into your head. It makes you think something will jump out, scare you half to death and eat what remains of your sanity alive. Spoiler: that doesn‚Äôt happen. Except for one area, I‚Äôll explain below. This isn‚Äôt a hardcore scare title like Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It‚Äôs far tamer by comparison while holding its own. I was often thinking that some dark fantasy creature such as Cthulhu was behind the scenes. It was amusing when that theory was half confirmed. The game will do its best to unnerve you. So long as you let it. There‚Äôs only one section of the map where jump scares are present. It‚Äôs in a mine and they sort of warn you that it‚Äôs coming. Sort of. And it‚Äôs mostly optional unless you want a 100% completion rating. At least, I‚Äôm fairly certain its optional. The scare is when you‚Äôre running around in a mining maze, searching for clues to open a large door in the center of it. In this area, is an undead miner who‚Äôs been cursed. While you‚Äôre walking around, if you hear a telltale noise you should immediately turn around and go the other way. Otherwise, BOO. You have to start from the beginning of the maze. PC Settings & OptimizationOptimization wise, this game leaves a bit to be desired. You will need to tweak your graphics options to get the best performance as running everything on high will drag the performance down hard. I noticed that Anti-Aliasing and Texture Filtering were the big performance hogs. Oh and there is constant texture loading, which will cause your game to ‚Äústutter‚Äù frequently as it loads them. This is a problem that affects a lot of computers and it‚Äôs immersion breaking. Additionally, if you‚Äôre not running a 16:9 resolution, the game will letterbox/pillarbox. Which I find to be frankly inexcusable for a native PC game to be this way. I can‚Äôt figure out why the devs didn‚Äôt scale the resolutions properly, it‚Äôs not like the Unreal engine can‚Äôt do it. PCGamingWiki has a installable solution to fix this as well as grant you multi-monitor and ultra-widescreen options. Additionally, while there is a proper Field-of-View slider in the options, (70-120) it crops the image in order to do it. Overall, while the game does run/scale well (and it does so long as you tweak about in the settings), the remaining problems are less excusable. Also, saving is only done in chunks so you might revert some of your actions when quitting and reloading. Redux Edition Quick ThoughtsI gave the Redux edition a quick run through and they seem to have fixed a lot of the problems the original game had. The micro-stutter is completely gone, there's no more pillarboxing as the resolution scales and performance generally seems to be better, if more taxing on machines. Saving is now done every time you act now too. FoV is still a crop effect but I'll let it be. There's also a bunch of tweaks and visual improvements added that you probably won't notice. There's no story difference between the two editions so if you can, play the redux. If that's too taxing, play the original. Kudos to the devs for doing this for free. Final ThoughtsThe atmosphere and mystery makes for a compelling experience. While it does have a lot of adventure/walking simulator aspects to it, it still keeps the player involved the entire time. The atmosphere of a decaying rural area known as Red River Valley is simply intriguing. The psychological horror just works so well. Jump scares are rare but there‚Äôs something that eats at you the entire time. When finished, the game will leave you with more questions than answers though not in the ‚Äúfind out in the sequel‚Äù sort of way. I should note that the characters are rather cliche but when I consider the ending, it works and feels intentional. Visually, the game looks superb and the audio is top notch. If you're looking for a fun mystery/exploration through a decaying rural area, give The Vanishing of Ethan Carter a go.Read This and More Like It on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												This is a beautiful and interesting game which, with a few nudges and tweaks could have been even better. Initially there is no plot - you just have to find Ethan. Unfortunately, there is also no guidance or advice about how to use the tricks at your disposal. I respect the designers' intention to not hold your hand, but a couple of pointers would have helped. For example, there is nothing to prevent you from wandering into another area before completing the puzzles in the first. I would guess it's possible to complete the game while missing most of the puzzles due to over-eager exploration. There's also no clue about how to use the psychic powers to locate clues, which can leave you searching for a tiny object in a large map. Finally, the game's puzzles could really do with a few more elements: one sequence is unlocked by simply returning an object to its original location. The psychic detective thing works nicely, though, and the idea of Ethan creating fantastical stories from modest family dramas is a compelling device which keeps the game moving forward. Graphically, this is about as good as Unreal 3 gets: high-res textures and masses of foliage show this was written for the PC but, as usual with U3, shaders are a bit sparse and there is no use of POM or tessellation. Most importantly, the world looks and feels real, and this is enhanced by the moody music. Given how few names are mentioned in the credits, the whole game is a pretty impressive experience. It's Dear Esther with a few more things to do, and there's nothing wrong with that. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												My favorite author is H.P. Lovecraft, so I make a point of checking out every game or movie that claims to be inspired by his work.  Usually the end result is pretty weak sauce, but sometimes I find epic experiences like Eternal Darkness or Dark Corners of the Earth ... or shorter, but still powerful stories like Ethan Carter.The game's story is more in line with Lovecraft's early work, with the focus on internalized existential angst with a smattering of references to the wider mythos and the power of dreams.  It's a slower, more personal, self-contained story, rather than one about ancient aliens rising up from terrible slumber to end humanity, which is fine.  Gameplay is all about investigating a series of murders in the gorgeously rendered Red Creek Valley while searching for Ethan Carter.  There is no combat and no way to die (although there is a gamebreaking bug that I at first mistook for character death towards the end, if you solve one of the puzzles before the final murder, that requires you to close the game and continue from the previous save).The unique method of sensing the psychic residue of strong emotions and reconstructing the timelines of the murders is clever and provides the only real "action" to what is primarily a short story you get to walk through and witness.  There are no outcomes to change, no secret endings, no agency for you as a player at all, really, other than the order in which you solve the murders.Graphically, the game is beautiful, alternating between peaceful and creepy, as needed.  The environments look and sound real and are the key to the experience.  Lesser visuals would have hurt the immersion.  The character models are less impressive by comparison, but the voice acting makes up for that and provides some believable personalities.  I would recommend you disable Motion Blur in the Graphics options, as I found it nauseating and a distraction from the great artwork done for the game.Total game time, exploring every possible location is 4-5 hrs, and for an $8 game, I can't really complain.  I pay more than that to see a 2 hr movie at the theatre.  Replayability is practically nil, however.  Once you have solved a murder or puzzle the hard way (without a guide - using one will only hurt your experience in the long run), you can easily burn through it again without much effort, further cutting down the game time to less than 2 hrs, easily, accounting for walking time and watching the cutscenes.  You'd be better off introducing someone else to the game, rather than play through it multiple times.  Then you could discuss the ending!For an additional $4, you can get a digital map, poster, making of document, and the origianl soundtrack, which I purchased to support the developers and found worth it for the great atmospheric music alone.If you want to experience a beautiful visual tale of mystery and the occult in the vein of H.P. Lovecraft, there's hardly a better way to spend a lazy afternoon.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												What can I say about Ethan Carter without spoiling it's story? Not a lot other than: I really, REALLY liked it. It's easily one of the most athmospheric and beautiful games I've ever played. The setting, the tone, the influences, the story, the puzzles, everything just worked for me. As I said, I don't want to spoil anything about it, as I think this is one of the games you should come in as freash as you can be, with as little knowledge of it as possible. It's not a long game, but it also don't have any filler material, only quality stuff. And it's a top experience from start to finish because of that. I think this is also one of the games, that could've been easily messed up, if this would've been some AAA-retail game with 20 hours of content. I really think the lenght is perfect as it is.If I would have to suggest something, that IMO would've maybe made the game even better, it's probably: few more puzzles would have fitted in, eventhough there are some secrets also.Only real critique I had with the game is it's saving system: if you have some mystery in the middle of solving and you go and do something and see the "Saving scene...", which usually leads you to believe, that everything you've done/found so far is saved, it doesn't save the mystery that is in the middle of solving. So, just a tip: solve all the mysteries you start before quitting, so you'll avoid playing things thru all over again.All in all this game is a hell of a debut from the small team hailing from Poland - The Astronauts. And if they'll do more of these narrative game experiences in the future, it'll be a day 1 buy for me. I'm really looking forward what they'll decide to do next.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Beginning with a pointedly vague premise of your being some kind of detective on the trail of the titular missing child, the game barely holds your hand as you discover your paranormal investigative abilities and begin to piece together a series of strange events in a remote countryside. That lack of hand holding is more a part of the gameplay than one might initially realize as it ultimately provokes a sort of trial and error process that is in itself an investigation. Despite a few fairly simple puzzles, the game is mostly about discovery. While primarily linear, there are various clues and revelations lying just off the beaten path, many of which ultimately need to be discovered to complete the game, but that (whether found later or during the course of your primary investigation) don‚Äôt stymie the pace of the game.The game‚Äôs visuals are excellent, featuring not only the river valley vistas seen in the early part of the game, but beautifully dilapidated interiors and dank caves as well. The audio as well is great, with a near perfect score, quality voice acting, and immersive environmental sound. The GUI overlays are brilliant and are realized in such a manner as not feel like an interface, but instead like an extension of the protagonist‚Äôs investigative abilities. The ultimate result is a greater sense of immersion and that is a large part of Ethan Carter‚Äôs triumph.Throughout the nearly four hours I spent with The Vanishing of Ethan Carter I was almost completely enraptured by it, spurred on both by a sense of wonderment at the world before my eyes and also by a drive to discover the truth of the mystery at hand. It‚Äôs difficult to talk about the story at all without spoiling anything except to say that even when predictable, Ethan Carter delivers with a compelling emotional gravitas. I honestly can‚Äôt recommend this game enough to fans of first person adventure games, especially Amenisia, Gone Home, or Dear Esther. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is worth picking up at any price.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												I've just played this through and I loved every minute.This is an open world puzzle game with an intriguing mystery storyline with horror elements. You take the role of a detective investigating the titular disappearance of a young boy, Ethan Carter. It's pretty hard to discuss the narrative further without giving away spoilers. It has been described as Lovecraftian, I would say there are a few nods to Lovecraft and the Cthulhu Mythos, but it's not the basis of the whole story.The puzzles are logical and not too tough to solve once you understand the mechanic. I did feel that the later murders were a little easier to solve and felt like less work had been put into them compared to say the first one. The puzzles are not all the same though, and there is a good variety to keep the player interested. I would suggest avoiding checking walkthroughs or guides as the puzzles are all achievable with a bit of thought. The graphics are stunning, the level of detail is very high and it must have taken a huge amount of work to create the game world. Pretty much everywhere you look there are amazing views and the landscape is very serene and peaceful. There is a known issue of flashing red lights in the trees which affects Radeon cards, and I did observe it but it wasn't frequent enough to cause a distraction.A few people have complained about the length of this game. You can expect 5-7 hours of gameplay depending on how good you are at solving the puzzles. I personally think that is pretty reasonable. I'd much rather have 6 hours of quality gameplay than 12 hours of filler.Anyway, I'm definitely recommending this.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
A Paladin‚Äôs Steam Review: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. A Subtly Disturbing Yet Compelling Mystery Game.Genre: First Person Atmospheric Story Driven Mystery with Psychological Horror ElementsDeveloper & Publisher: The AstronautsPlatform Support: Windows, PS4. Mac & Linux "Coming Soon". Business Model: Base Game. Copy Purchased by MyselfOverall Gameplay ThoughtsVanishing comes very, very close to a Walking Simulator. There really isn‚Äôt a failure state, your actions don‚Äôt really affect the game in any meaningful way and the game expects you to experience a lot of it. The only influence you have is exploring the world of Red Creek Valley, solving the puzzles and, by extension, the mystery Paul Prospero is here to solve. Oh right, that‚Äôs the guy who you‚Äôre controlling and hear monologue as you explore the valley. So, you'll walk along at a fairly steady pace (there's a reasonably faster sprint as well), drink in the atmosphere while you search for clues of Ethan's whereabouts. All the while discovering that there's something creepy and sinister beneath the surface. Red Creek Valley is divided up into multiple areas, each containing a major puzzle or two for you to solve. Puzzles, for the most part, boil down to finding all the objects within a given area and figuring out how they all go together. The music playing in the background will clue you in on whether you‚Äôve left the given area very subtly. Which is helpful because you‚Äôll never need to leave an area in order to solve that particular puzzle. There aren‚Äôt any random items on the other side of the map that you have to find. It should be noted that it isn't required to solve these puzzle areas in any particular order, they can be done at any time. Outside of soaking in the sights and experiencing the strange events going on, there‚Äôs not much else to do. However, I always felt like I was involved. There wasn't any boring section I felt forced to walk through. It might help that Red Creek Valley appealed to me. Being able to see the burned out buildings, the rusted train cars and nature reclaiming the area, it really intrigued me. It's a feel of history and decay that Vanishing goes out of its way to really sell to the player. It feels like a real place and it‚Äôs setup like a real place. I think that helped me enjoy the game more. Atmosphere & JumpscaresThe atmosphere ate away at me. Slowly, creepily, I would sometimes jump at my phone beeping at me. It‚Äôs insidious how this game gets into your head. It makes you think something will jump out, scare you half to death and eat what remains of your sanity alive. Spoiler: that doesn‚Äôt happen. Except for one area, I‚Äôll explain below. This isn‚Äôt a hardcore scare title like Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It‚Äôs far tamer by comparison while holding its own. I was often thinking that some dark fantasy creature such as Cthulhu was behind the scenes. It was amusing when that theory was half confirmed. The game will do its best to unnerve you. So long as you let it. There‚Äôs only one section of the map where jump scares are present. It‚Äôs in a mine and they sort of warn you that it‚Äôs coming. Sort of. And it‚Äôs mostly optional unless you want a 100% completion rating. At least, I‚Äôm fairly certain its optional. The scare is when you‚Äôre running around in a mining maze, searching for clues to open a large door in the center of it. In this area, is an undead miner who‚Äôs been cursed. While you‚Äôre walking around, if you hear a telltale noise you should immediately turn around and go the other way. Otherwise, BOO. You have to start from the beginning of the maze. PC Settings & OptimizationOptimization wise, this game leaves a bit to be desired. You will need to tweak your graphics options to get the best performance as running everything on high will drag the performance down hard. I noticed that Anti-Aliasing and Texture Filtering were the big performance hogs. Oh and there is constant texture loading, which will cause your game to ‚Äústutter‚Äù frequently as it loads them. This is a problem that affects a lot of computers and it‚Äôs immersion breaking. Additionally, if you‚Äôre not running a 16:9 resolution, the game will letterbox/pillarbox. Which I find to be frankly inexcusable for a native PC game to be this way. I can‚Äôt figure out why the devs didn‚Äôt scale the resolutions properly, it‚Äôs not like the Unreal engine can‚Äôt do it. PCGamingWiki has a installable solution to fix this as well as grant you multi-monitor and ultra-widescreen options. Additionally, while there is a proper Field-of-View slider in the options, (70-120) it crops the image in order to do it. Overall, while the game does run/scale well (and it does so long as you tweak about in the settings), the remaining problems are less excusable. Also, saving is only done in chunks so you might revert some of your actions when quitting and reloading. Redux Edition Quick ThoughtsI gave the Redux edition a quick run through and they seem to have fixed a lot of the problems the original game had. The micro-stutter is completely gone, there's no more pillarboxing as the resolution scales and performance generally seems to be better, if more taxing on machines. Saving is now done every time you act now too. FoV is still a crop effect but I'll let it be. There's also a bunch of tweaks and visual improvements added that you probably won't notice. There's no story difference between the two editions so if you can, play the redux. If that's too taxing, play the original. Kudos to the devs for doing this for free. Final ThoughtsThe atmosphere and mystery makes for a compelling experience. While it does have a lot of adventure/walking simulator aspects to it, it still keeps the player involved the entire time. The atmosphere of a decaying rural area known as Red River Valley is simply intriguing. The psychological horror just works so well. Jump scares are rare but there‚Äôs something that eats at you the entire time. When finished, the game will leave you with more questions than answers though not in the ‚Äúfind out in the sequel‚Äù sort of way. I should note that the characters are rather cliche but when I consider the ending, it works and feels intentional. Visually, the game looks superb and the audio is top notch. If you're looking for a fun mystery/exploration through a decaying rural area, give The Vanishing of Ethan Carter a go.Read This and More Like It on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												This game is more or less:10% Myst20% Dear Esther20% Gone Home50% Lovecraftian Horror MysteryNow the (non-spoilery) review:Let me begin by saying this game is right up my alley so I may be slightly biased in the positive direction. Graphics: This game is beautiful, and not just because of the extremely high quality visuals. This game does a better job using high fidelity graphics and environment design to create a deep sense of immersion and an engrossing atmosphere than any I've played in recent years except perhaps The Last of Us. The wind, weather effects, lighting, textures, richly detailed and expertly designed environments all work together perfectly to create an eerie, atmospheric and very "real" feeling world. 10/10Gameplay Design: Engaging mechanics of play isn't the reason to play this kind of game. For a game that claims to "not do any hand holding" most of the puzzles are‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•easy, although some of them are pretty original and well executed. Other than that exploring semi-linear environments is the only way you directly interact with the games world. However it is a perfectly sufficient manner to get you through the primary draw of the game; the story and environment . 6.5/10Environment(lvl) Design: This is where the game really shines. I don't think I've ever played a game where the world felt so real. The placement of every rock, log, patch of grass, door, etc. is perfect, and the environments are detailed without feeling "over done". The visual reference point I keep coming back to is The Last of Us but while it was a beautiful game with excellent visual design the world did feel stylized. Ethan Carter on the other hand has many areas that feel like places I've actually been, so close in fact that it should be uncanny, but instead it just adds a whole other level of immersion and engagement, especially when they introduce supernatural elements.Specific praises include: How well they use visual highlighting to guide the player to places of interest (including both actual light, and the shape of the landscape). Excellent use of the outdoor environment to hide the borders of the levels, this place only has a few places that are straight up "invisible walls" but you only bump into them if you're doing things that don't make sense in the context of the game, and the word is so beautifully realized and expertly designed that you forget about them the minute you step back onto the path the game intends you to take. It guides you without it feeling like it's shoving you down a hallway, something that is incredibly difficult to do. 10/10 Story: It's pretty difficult to critique the story it in detail without spoiling it, but here goes. It's well presented, and it starts out very intriguing but I called the twist ending about a third of the way through and it's pretty steeped in the tropes of supernatural mystery. It's not terribly original, but the way you experience the story is novel and engaging enough to elevate it past the written words. 8/10Overall Experience: The game won't change the way you think about games, and it isn't quite as gut wrenching or mind bending as other similar games, but if you enjoy games like the only I likened it to, give it a look. It's beautiful, atmospheric, and genuinely intriguing and engaging (while you're playing it, once you have the full picture it loses some of it's magic).One last praise I had is how well it paces itself, and how it maintains an atmosphere of mystery and subtle horror without every being terrifying the way something like Outlast, or even Amnesia is. There where many times it could have taken a turn and thrown in a jump scare, or a tense stealth/chase sequence, but it choose to instead be morose, bittersweet, and contemplative, and I think the game is better for it. 8/10Bottom Line: 8/10

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												An entertaining mystery/adventure game with a compelling narrative and striking visuals.You play Paul Prospero, the Philip Marlowe of the supernatural world, picking up one last case after receiving a letter from fellow mystic and absent-minded storyteller, the boy, Ethan Carter. He's vanished, so it's time to put that second-sight to use and track him down!Graphically the game is quite stunning, and when combined with an eerie and ominous score, lends itself to a genuine Lovecraftian atmosphere. There are moments where you may inexplicably look behind you.The puzzles aren't anything to write home about, and I thought, could have been more challenging, but they will immerse you in the story. The narrative is well paced, at no point did trudge on to the next scene wondering what I was doing. It felt as though I had sufficiently adventured by the time I reached the ending, which is certainly worth it, bringing your supernatural connection to the young Ethan Carver full circle.The whole thing will take about four hours, a little more if you go achievement hunting.Have fun!9/10

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Hello guys!The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great story/game that, in my opinion, should be tried out by every person who loves mysticsm and craves for a good written tale. At first, the game will impress you with stunning landscape views and beautiful graphics (although at some places it wasn't polished to the limits). It feels real. I mean really real, although it sounds kind of ridiculous. Well, at least when you do not look really closely. Wind is slowly swinging grass, tress, bushes and etc. Combining this with abandoned railroad and houses and, of course, mountain range environment the game creates feelings of lonelyness and melancholy. But after a few tens of minutes player will realise that something really weird is happening around there. Or maybe was happening... After this, the game will make you think. Not too hard, not too much. but still think... How to solve, where's the catch. Because the more you solve, the more story you'll uncover. And thus the game gets as interesting, as it is beautiful. And even if you won't be able to solve everything and leave some mysteries behind, you will still get to the very end of the game to see, to know what really happened there... And now i'll put aside my emotions and feelings and try to point out some pros and cons of this game. Pros:-interesting story with a few or even none flaws in it;-breathtaking and detailed environment;-kind of empty but still alive world;-really good soundtrack;-simple game mechanics;-even more interesting when played with someone.Objective cons:-seems to be overpriced for its length;-later on the puzzles give you the feeling that they are a bit unfinished (at least some of them);-is really violent (I wouldn't recommend this for underaged or really sensitive people);-Lots of backtracking.Subjective cons:-puzzles were too easy for me with most of them taking like 5-7 minutes to solve them;-in my opinion, it would be great if the puzzles had a little different solution mechanics and would make you to think more;-i'm not sure if this was my machine but I had some minor lags and one bug that needed a game restart to be solved.For the record, I played this with my girlfriend who isn't a fan of computer games. But she enjoyed this game a lot, loved the story, loved the time we spent for it. So... This game is really worth to buy and play, even if it's short and overpriced. Want to buy a book with a good plot and sophisticated point of view towards the world? Do it... But consider this game as well, because it's almost as good as any of Stephen Kings' horror stories.Short update: in my review the time spent for this game is not shown correctly - with long strolls and taking time to enjoy the views this game took me about 6 hours to complete it with doing all the achievements.As of 2016 - 11 - 27 I'm really happy to add that with tVoEC redux they fixed backtracking issues.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
 Review Time!!!!       So ill first start out with my original thought of game pre purchase.  I like all sorts of games so long as they bring something to the table that intrigues me.  In this case i had watched the trailer and the gameplay videos on steam, and decided that this game had first off amazing visuals (not just graphically but landscape design was pretty great)  and a style of game play that just struck me as a refreshing change of pace to my growing stack of story driven/puzzle games.  I had discussed the gameplay to my friend, (as we went upon an expedition into the forest to chop trees for quickly arriving winter) then nothing. I guess along the journey I had expressed interest in the purchase of the game, but only whence my financial portfolio was performing better. Fast forward a time we are cutting more wood we arrive back at the casa and i have a steam message.  Turns out whilst i was preoccupied my friend had found time to purchase the game without me knowing, and left me a message  We should play the game upon its download and then something about drinking yada yada  twas a great message.     Game installs we click play and the pre game window launches.  I enjoy when a game does this.  Not only does it remind me about changing the graphics settings, but makes the whole process much easier especially if the game is like Fable Anniversary and has the worst computer interface i have ever had the misfortune of dealing with.  After a few moments of turning everything to  maximum overdrive  it was finally time to play.  The Games Main Menu was very simple nice scenery of a meadow i believe now that i think about it i cant really remember, but i do remember a tree in the bottom left corner. There were four or so options we clicked new game or whatever it is to begin our adventure into saving some small child in a basement from his moth.... oh wait thats the  Binding of Isaac  .... to save a boy whom has vanished.     The game opens into an amazing graphically vivid environment.  Slight nuissance of blurring around the non focused center area of screen, but its an attempt to be more realistic i guess.  Controls are very simple which is good because there is no tutorial.  Straight into  Murder Train  mystery solving.  The solving of events is pretty simple; find dead guy, restore crime scene, and use dead guy's memories (I personally think that Paul Prospero is Dumbledore in disguise hence the use of pensieve) to discover a series of events that you must piece together to gain access to the dead spirits last major memory as its soul is torn from the world of the living.   BOOM  Solved my first scene psychic powers FTW.  Thus far into the game about 15 minutes or so, and the daunting question begins to arrive  "How long is this game?"  This question never popped into my mind before, but story driven games are notorious for being rather short. I personally am ok with a game thats a few hours of great story because hey its a genre with usually a better story than an fps, but without the  pchew pchew.   Although at this  point you are also wondering is there going to be a good storyline as well. All you know is  there is an entity named the  Sleeper  controlling people. Ethan is resistant to its call, and he is in trouble.      That is it for giveaways to the story and progress that takes place now its the moment everyones been waiting for.  My friend and i finished the game it roughly 2 hours and 30 minutes.  Thats full completion all miscellaneous events and all story driven ones.  The story had its share of depth, but id say most of the depth came from the miscellaneous events and tidbits of  Ethan's  stories.  Twice were we caught off guard by sudden bouts of quiet to super loud doubtfully intentional jump scares.... Ok maybe one was intentional, and it got us because here we are joking about  should we run..... no he disappeared OHHH SH** . Anywho it was fun.  The ending was in my personal oppinion lack luster with everything you gather through out the story you start to see whats up.  Atleast we did.  As for exact events we didn't have that figured and it made for an interesting addition but we both felt strange about it.     Still no regrets from either of us about the $20 dollar price tag, and those whom complain that they just spent $5 bucks per hour of enjoyment we spent $10 and i will say $10 bucks per hour for a great time and pleasure of playing this game is worth it to keep this group of developers making games.  My suggestion is buy it call a friend have him pick up a six pack of a nice lager, and play the game. If you know someone who has this game call em up plan a day to drink and play it and just enjoy the time.  Maybe they themselves are regretting the purchase buy the beer and say hey now you've gotten some money back, (at this point they wont care because they have now officially enjoyed the game for a second playthrough) and you will have solved  The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.
