content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
In BriefSomewhere between walk-'em-up and adventure game, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter blends the best elements of both.Most valuable resource:  The atmosphere.Of interest to: people who like their walk-'em-ups with just a tad more gameplay.The Vanishing of Ethan Carter received a lot of buzz in the indie-sphere, and rightly so.  It also has its detractors, and I can understand why.  There is just enough game here for it to be unequivocally a game, unlike other narrative-driven walking simulators like Dear Esther and Gone Home and thus, like Eidolon - another gamified stroller - Ethan Carter left itself open to criticism focusing only on the game elements.Now don't get me wrong, the game elements here are brilliant.  You are a supernatural investigator who stumbles across murder victims, hunts for clues using your psychic sense, assembles them, then gets to see little still poses of the victim and their murderer assembled around the scene.  By tagging them in the correct chronological order, you get to view a cutscene that explains what happened.  This denouement is masterfully done.  The process of stumbling across and then piecing together all the elements of the crime is entertaining, and doesn't break your immersion in the tense atmosphere the game is building by forcing you to involve yourself in mindless tasks or fiddly interfaces.But while these murders drive the narrative, the crime scene investigation definitely plays second fiddle to you just walking around this town.  I think the balance is just right, but for those who like more game in their game, the short running time combined with the few instances of this interesting mechanic equals not much game.  And I think that's a real shame, because the beauty of this game is in the way it artfully places you in a plausible scenario dealing with increasingly implausible elements that all have such gravity because the scene, the mood, the atmosphere are all so engrossing and so foreboding.The one criticism I do have is that that one wonderful mechanic is not explained.  It is barely referenced that you have this extra sense, and how your window on the past expands by assembling clues is never mentioned at all.  It doesn't help that the very first scene you encounter, the one where your powers are introduced, is completely atypical, lacking a body or any clues to assemble, and using a different visual to literally every other instance of the sense that occurs the entire duration of the game.  As far as communicating mechanics organically through gameplay goes, that's a cardinal sin.  I feel like the developers have heard this complaint before, and have inserted a warning up-front that the game does not hand-hold as a defence against this criticism, but if you find your players are googling "ethan carter touch not working" so frequently that google autocompletes the search three words in you've not communicated well enough.  And that's a real shame, because having to backtrack to redo the puzzles you didn't realise were puzzles kinda breaks the flow of the narrative and takes you out of the game. I do want to especially call out the jump scare section.  Ethan Carter is that rarest of beasts: a horror(-ish) game with an effective and appropriate jump scare.  Half way through the game, when the tension has been built and you're starting to get a sense that these are more than just mundane murders, this terrifying section comes out of nowhere, with no warning, and is genuinely terrifying.  Not just shocking or unexpected, but dreadful.  The fact that this section was managed so well is all you need to know to be sure that the whole game is subtle and intelligent and very expertly crafted as an experience.And it's beautiful, as all walk-'em-ups must be.  Unlike Mind: Path to Thalamus's saturated surreality, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is delicate, and wistful, and melancholic, but every inch as artistically gorgeous.  Take frequent scenic screenshots and you will be set for desktop wallpapers for a good long time.As a piece of Innsmouth writing, it is utterly on-pitch in its length and narrative progression.  If you're a fan of the understated horror of actual Lovecraft, rather than the Cthulu monsterism that has taken over the horror genre, this is a perfect experience for you.  It's not a long game, but it is exactly the right length.That said, I do hope there will be a sequel.  The set-up in terms of mechanics and theme here makes that perfectly possible, and it would be a real shame if we didn't get to play with this system again.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												I'm old.I've played 'Pong' on a Saba Videoplay console, 'Pac Man' on an Atari VCS, 'The Hobbit' on a Sinclair ZX Spectrum, 'The Castles of Doctor Creep' on a C64, 'Defender of the Crown' on an Amiga and hundreds of other games on consoles, home and personal computers.Like I said, I'm old.Up to this point, I've NEVER played - no, experienced - something that intense like 'The Vanishing of Ethan Carter' (TVoEC).This game made a lasting impression on me and I still think about it, although I finished TVoEC months ago.For me, as a fan of old Stephen King, David Lynch and H. P. Lovecraft works, this game was a revelation. It created the perfect mood, the right atmosphere, with amazing graphics, an ingenious soundtrack that creeps into your subconscious mind and the strange feeling of pleasant but spooky loneliness.Yes, the riddles might be easy to see through for an experienced gamer and let's be honest, TVoEC is not a very long game. But this doesn't have to be a disadvantage. I for example prefer a typical 6-episodes season of a British TV production over a 22-episodes season of e.g. an American or a German TV production in general.Those 6 episodes are packed with just good stuff and I enjoy watching them again and again, whereas 22 episodes often contain unnecessary fillers.In other words, I prefer quality over quantity. Maybe because I‚Äôm old.‚ÄòThe Vanishing of Ethan Carter‚Äô is a high quality game.This is a game for your heart, not for your heart rate.I can't wait to see with what ‚ÄòThe Astronauts‚Äô come up next.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												I bought this during the summer sale for about 8 bucks and it was completely worth it. Beautiful game, amazing atmosphere, haunting music, and a nice creepy little story. Minimal action, you're just playing for the exposition but it does that quite well. It's in a similar vein as Stephen King's old works, with some Lovecraft thrown in as well. Take your time and explore, and you won't be disappointed.That said, it is a very short game, without much replay value once you know the story. Definitely worth playing, but maybe wait til it's on sale to try. Took me under 3.5 hours to clear completely.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												This game is visually stunning, atmospheric, captivating, and intriguing. There is little to nothing in the way of action, and overall it plays more like a mystery or puzzle game than survival horror (though it has those elements as well). If you're looking for a shooter, or a fast-paced pulse pounding survival horror game, this isn't it.It is, however, a masterfully executed, immersive, narrative experience reminiscent of Twin Peaks and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. The ways the player is given to interact with the environment and the story are both novel and intuitive, and the game has an unintrusive, minimal interface that fits well with the tone and theme of the game.I've been seeing this game compared to Dear Esther, which is a game I hate. Apart from generally seeming to have been constructed with more care, this game differs from Dear Esther in one very important, fundamental way: It gives the player things to do, and makes them feel like they are involved in the story. I felt a need to address this because the frequent comparisons between the two had caused me to avoid The Vanishing of Ethan Carter for quite some time. When I finally played it I was pleasantly surprised to find that this comparison does not hold up under scrutiny.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												This is a beautiful and interesting game which, with a few nudges and tweaks could have been even better. Initially there is no plot - you just have to find Ethan. Unfortunately, there is also no guidance or advice about how to use the tricks at your disposal. I respect the designers' intention to not hold your hand, but a couple of pointers would have helped. For example, there is nothing to prevent you from wandering into another area before completing the puzzles in the first. I would guess it's possible to complete the game while missing most of the puzzles due to over-eager exploration. There's also no clue about how to use the psychic powers to locate clues, which can leave you searching for a tiny object in a large map. Finally, the game's puzzles could really do with a few more elements: one sequence is unlocked by simply returning an object to its original location. The psychic detective thing works nicely, though, and the idea of Ethan creating fantastical stories from modest family dramas is a compelling device which keeps the game moving forward. Graphically, this is about as good as Unreal 3 gets: high-res textures and masses of foliage show this was written for the PC but, as usual with U3, shaders are a bit sparse and there is no use of POM or tessellation. Most importantly, the world looks and feels real, and this is enhanced by the moody music. Given how few names are mentioned in the credits, the whole game is a pretty impressive experience. It's Dear Esther with a few more things to do, and there's nothing wrong with that. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Spectacular. A very beautiful (literally) example of noir detective mystery story telling with enough horror elements to drag you in without the usual frustration or repulsion or terror that usually comes with it (I stopped playing Dead Space 2 times before I finally picked up the courage to finish it. I still haven't finished Amnesia!)If you've liked Gone Home, you'll love this. This game places story & atmosphere at the forefront so that's a big hint to you on whether you want to pick it up. There's very little action, no health or time limit or such stress factors...just you and a story that you can peel apart at your own pace and from your own angles. And it's a very touching, emotional story indeed that I feel ended in a pretty satisfying way, contrary to what many reviews say. Take your time with it; explore. There's lots to admire just by strolling through the sprawling forest landscape.Still, there're definitely game elements that draw you in and keep you engaged, besides the jaw-dropping scenery. Puzzles lie sprawled across the map waiting for you to discover and solve. They're not too hard - each puzzle was just enough of a challenge without too much frustration involved, and it's satisfying when you reach each answer, while at the same time, more of the story unfolds from there.Which brings me to perhaps the only sore point: the save system is quite vague at first: the game only saves after each solved puzzle, which means you shouldn't explore too much and then quit the game without solving something first, and once - only once - did I encounter a bug that made me lose about 20 minutes of progress. It's not really serious, but it's there.Overall, I'd heavily recommend the game. It's a little pricey normally (I bought it in the autumn sale), but it's definitely an unforgettable experience you have to try.

												The Astronauts have built a gorgeous, unsettling world to explore.  The atmosphere, aided by the sound and music design and the minimal interface, is engrossing and lingers with you (with the possible exception of the voice acting, which is - perhaps intentionally - less than completely convincing).The underlying plot is nothing ground-breaking, but it unfolds in sublime ways with twist(s) that never feel insulting to the player.  There is always a feeling of more stories, more mysteries, more history shimmering at the periphery.  All in all, I would gladly have spent two or three times as long in that world if there had been the content to support it -- one or two more puzzles (or perhaps just more depth to the existing ones) might have better rounded out the already wonderful experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Wonderfully thought provoking, hauntingly memorable supernatural adventure game.  Not quite the revelation in gaming the press would have you believe, as the game is resolutely old school in it's appproach.  Ethan Carter rather reminds me of the old Infocom text adventures of the 1980's, the hardest of which more often than not contained equally as obtuse game mechanics as Ethan Carter and fantastically written plots.Ethan Carter looks stunning and is drenched in atmospheric visuals, the sound does a good job too.  On the downside there's some noticeable graphical lagging in certain areas on any quality setting and the musical triggers are a bit too abrupt when changing track.  Some of the character models are somewhat at odds with the beautiful environments too, with models looking a bit underdeveloped facially and texturally.The story and atmosphere are what sets Ethan Carter apart from the crowd however.  The story is told almost entirely through clues in the environment and sparse objects lying around, from which events must be reconstructed in an impressive, forensically supernatural fashion. The devs should be lauded for such a refreshing take on adventure gaming, a ray of light in today's wretched UBI/EA/DLC/AAA/CoD dominated con-fest of a gaming industry.In summary then, Ethan Carter is a short but essential Lovecraftian tale. An expertly crafted adventure game that puts triple A studios to shame with it's bold direction, visual story telling and technical prowess.  Buy this game, it's a game you won't forget in a hurry

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Let's get a few things out of the way first. I'm not sure whether to recommend this game or not, but I can recognise the developers created something extraordinary here, and that at least deserved being mentioned.This game is basically a walking simulator, but unlike for example The Stanley Parable, there are no alternate routes or endings. Replayability is non-existent here. Depending on how leisurely you play and how fast you resort to walkthroughs, you'll get about two to five hours out of this 'game'. In that sense you're probably thinking this game is overpriced, and I agree.I won't go into too much detail about the story, as that really is the meat of the game. I don't want to take away from that. But essentially, you are Paul Prospero, a detective with a keen eye for the supernatural, and you have come to Red Creek Valley per request of Ethan Carter's fanmail. As you solve murders and puzzles, the overarching plot reveals itself to you through cutscenes and voice-overs.The way this works is you are dropped into a gorgeous, sprawling open-world with the clues scattered about. This is very reminiscent of point-and-click games, but the difference is you can actually (un)intentionally skip puzzles or scenes and walk further into the world. But to get the ending, you'll have to eventually solve every puzzle. To summarize	 Top-notch visuals and music score make for a very eerie atmosphere. Easily the best part about the game.Absolutely zero replayability. Best when played through in a single sitting in my opinion. Try keeping a spoiler-free walkthrough handy if you don't like the idea of wandering aimlessly until you bump into a clue.The plot is alright to excellent, depending on your personal taste, but I don't think anyone can call it poor.If you like games such as The Stanley Parable, Dear Esther, or are otherwise interested in video games as an art, definitely pick this up if you catch it on sale. I can best summarize this game as being dropped into a gorgeous but gloomy lovecraftian film which you can explore and walk around in.That all being said, it's definitely not for everyone. I personally see this game for all its worth but it's hard to 'recommend' it in the typical sense.

												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a beautifuly designed masterpiece.The very moment you open your eyes, the game absolutely stuns with beautiful visuals and as you are gently walking your first steps in the world, you will immidiately feel that childish sense of wonder and excitement, but that is only the beginning of the beautifu and sad experience that awaits you. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter tells several stories tied by a single main narrative in an engaging and visually atractive way.The graphics are very good, the music is up to scratch and mirrors the mood of the various places visited throughout the game. I think the main downside of this title is how short the gameplay is. It took me just three hours to discover and complete all of the available stories and puzzles, as well as all but one achievement.If anyone's looking for an adventure game, like those of the Myst series, including Uru, you might find the puzzles not challenging enough, maybe even disappointing. However,  The Vanishing of Ethan Carter simply does not belong to this genre. It's more of a multimedia story. Not an adventure game, not a pure story like Dear Esther, but something inbetween.It's probably not a game I'm ever going to replay but I certainly concider it money well-spent. Playing through it felt like reading a book (and a decent one) in many ways. The most vibrant inspiration behind the storyline seems to be that drawn from the works of H. P. Lovecraft. However, subtle hints of the styles and interests represented by multiple other authors can be picked up by an attentive player.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Easily the best game I've played in quite a while. I played through it over two days ago and I still can't stop thinking about it. It takes around four hours to play through which may be a turn-off for some, but the story is so compelling and the graphics are so beautiful that it's hard to put down. The writing is smart and at times intentionally ambiguous, which allows the player to ponder some of the deeper implications of the events presented. The creators seem to be heavily influenced by classic science-fiction and horror literature, and throughout the game pay homage to masters of the macabre like Edgar Allan Poe and H.P. Lovecraft. All of this is presented to the player in a world that is frighteningly beautiful and isolating. The end result is a game that continues to haunt you well after you've completed it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												*MAY INCLUDE SPOILERS*I can most aptly characterize The Vanishing of Ethan Carter using its own words 'This game is a narrative experience that doesn't hold your hand'. To me, it's almost like a lovechild of Alan Wake and Dear Esther, combining brilliantly dark writing (reminissant of Edgar Allen Poe) and stunning life-like visuals (even well-textured foliage!) into an unforgettable masterpiece that shows the genre is still very much alive.The Vanishing of Ethan Carter explores ideas of broken souls, the human condition, a child's imigination and, apparently, vanishings.As I'm always fond of in games, there were some splendidly odd sequences (namely the space segment), yet nothing felt out of place. Every scene and aspect worked and flowed well.And I must comment on the sheer atmospheric genius - everything feels so alive, but you feel so alone. Yet with a lurking sense something or someone is waiting for you. The music compliments the atmosphere design perfectly, provoking emotional response and, not gonna lie, it gave me goosebumps.A beautiful metaphor and a loveletter to the genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an absolute beauty of a game, from its stunning environmental landscapes to the fantastic atmospheric sound effects that you hear while walking around. I feel that this game has a mix of L.A. Noire with Dear Esther and a bit of Amnesia: The Dark Descent thrown in.The story is very good and the ending is very good too. Although the game is pretty short, with only a 3-4 hour length in gameplay, it is still worth getting! Also, The Astronauts made a prequel comic which you can read to find out what happened before the events that take place in the game.The voice acting, although not the greatest I've heard, it is pretty good but don't expect to hear AAA voice actors in this gameThe environment as mentioned before is stellar and beautiful in many ways, I would recommend buying/playing this game on a computer that can actually handle it, although I was able to play it on the High settings, I did experience some sticking in areas where there is a lot of objects. And the FPS did choke down to even 10 FPS!Although I never saw one single loading screen, I did notice some bugs in the game, in one part I had to put a certain scene in chronological order and two of the player models were missing even though I could still arrange them how I wanted them to be, plus the game did crash once (but that was probably my PC chocking itself with the amount of stuff it had to handle)Even though the game is great, I wish they could of improved on some stuff. The place where you visit which is Red Creek Valley, is pretty big! I know that the developers wanted to immerse you into the game, but I wish there was a few maps placed into the environment like in the Mine (players who played this bit, you know which bit!) had. Plus some of the items you have to search you don't even realize until you almost reach the end,  SPOILER ALERT! - In one such example, where you enter in the beginning of the game through the tunnel, there are a set of traps which make part of the story, I didn't even know this until I reached the map at the end where it shows all the areas! And I had to travel all the way back to the start! Also, another example is the astronaut that takes you into space, how on earth would you know where it is until you reach the end and then you have to travel all the way back to save that scene!  Another thing which also annoyed me was where you are in the scene that took place, you would either have to find something or rearrange something, some of the items took me over 30 minutes to complete because I didn't know what on earth I was supposed to do! Also, the puzzles are a bit tricky until you get the hang of it!The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great game to play and a job well done to the developers as this was there first game by the company The Astronauts, although the game may be a bit short and it may be a bit frustrating at times, this is a great first person mystery game! PLEASE NOTE: Do not think that there isn't any scary areas in this game! Do not be fooled by the teaser trailers and trailers, there is a few jumpscares in this game! If you don't like a few jumpscares, be prepared when playing The Vanishing of Ethan Carter!  RECOMMENDED :)  THEPCGAMER'S BEST GAME IN STEAM LIBRARY! (What's this? :- Like some games get "Best Game of 2014" or "Best Indie Game", etc... So I have decided to make my own!)

For one, this small studio managed to make a game which has better graphics, more consistent gameplay and fewer bugs than the vast majority of titles published by the "bests" of the industry. 												Very enjoyable. One of those special productions that is more of an experience than just a game. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												It's been a long time since  I got immersed in a single player game, let alone do a short review of one. This is the kind of game you think about after shutting your PC down and going to bed. Despite it being quite short (took me about 4 hours and I wandered around the map a bit) I spread my playthrough across 3 days. After the first session it felt like I played the game for a solid 3+ hours, when in fact I played only one. This game does walking around and exploring right, I can tell you that much. You WANT to see what the areas have to offer - the music and visuals are incredible but simple at the same time. The area itself is also very "dark" in some parts - enough to make it a horror game if only the devs wanted to go that way. Good thing they didn't, though. The ending was beautiful for me, open for interpretation and it just was a pleasure to see it like 5 more times after I finished - hearing the characters voices and the great end song.Slight spoiler here - I found / solved all of the 'quests' before reaching the end and it truly saddens me when I saw youtubers just rolling through the game, not wandering around, not exploring, etc. Shows you the current state of gaming, really. I will do a second playthrough to understand the story better - it's like a good movie, you see things differently the second time around.Shout out to the Astronauts crew! This is a great game and I'm waiting for more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a good game. I thoroughly enjoyed it and I was captivated throughout.I played the Paranormal Investigative game all in one sitting. The game Last seven hours, taking into account some time used actually trying to figure out the clues or where to go next. I'll address this later.-Firstly the story:If you like the paranormal, Noir detectives and murder mysteries. This is your game, and I would recommend you get it ASAP. The narrative of the game is explained to you through flashback sequence; which occur when the player completes all the "clues" for a scene in the game. Even then it's not overbearing. A simple line from the protagonist and player, Paul Prospero details everything you need to know without taking you out of the immersion of the game. Another thing this games does very well.-The games world:The map of the game, although small, is detailed meticulously. This fact and the use of the engine mean you can immerse yourself in the world incredibly easily, with the help of the subtle narrative. I cannot imagine what this would be like in VR. The game play is not completely linear, but there are aspects; and rightly so, that are. Such as areas being blocked or just hidden until an event is triggered in the story. Otherwise you can visit anywhere in the map without restriction. One downfall to this is it can lead to a lot of back-tracking, which does cause annoyance at times. When you really just want to progress the story to find out what is happening.-Game MechanicsAs mentioned earlier the game tells it's story through a sequence of flashbacks, that the player instigates from restoring items to their original places at a crime scene. Adding, partially, the element of paranormal. Otherwise the game plays like a first person point and click adventure really. Personally I think that's what makes it good. It's not over complicated; and doesn't bar people from entry into the game. Also, more importantly, it doesn't take away from the detective work.One thing that I both praise and criticize the game in, is the lack of hints or hand-holding. On one hand this means how well you progress through the game is entirely up to your skill. However in certain cases this can lead to frustration when, to progress onto the next area you have to do something that isn't obvious at all.  When in the hydroelectric plant it's not at all explained that you need to turn off the last turbine to uncover a path across the river To conclude I definitely recommend this game. It's a fun paranormal investigative game, which had me on the edge of my seat throughout and left me wanting more when I had finished. While I haven't played this in VR I think it would add to the immersion of the whole game, while there probably wouldn't be a high chance of motion sickness due to the walking nature of this game. However if this is the case then there's an option to add a sight in the middle of the screen that could help.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an exceedingly beautiful game visually, a surprising and ultimately very sad game narratively.Gameplay-wise, the focus is exploration. It walks the line between being a walking simulator, a hidden objects game and (thanks due to a few simple, yet engaging puzzles) a classic point-and-click adventure. It's an engaging mix, especially due to the absolutely excellent score and aforementioned visuals; and you truly feel a bit like a detective as you investigate the game world.I can't think of a way to say more about the game without spoiling it or without becoming too subjective. Honestly, the official game description says plenty. I think if based on that and the screenshots you think the game would appeal to you; then there's a very good chance it will. It definitely was the case for me - I had a wonderful time exploring, and the story ended up personally resonating with me.

content:

												Technical:Doesn't support 21:9 or wider screen resolutions. Flawlesswidescreen fixes thisBuilt on the Unreal Engine, so performance is amazing and the graphics are breathtakingSeriously, buy the game, if only to bask in the gloriousness of the PC Master RaceMy thoughts:Masterpiece. Absolutely incredible at building an environment to play in.Little bit of a learning curve though. This game is a bit...different to play, than any other game I've played before. A lot of weird things go on, that can sometimes creep you out. Don't let your common sense grab hold of you, this is more along the lines of The Twilight Zone. Think of this title as a supernatural Nancy Drew, the the visual fidelity of Crysis, and the ability to tell a story on the level of Metro 2033. Stellar game, very much a 'proof of concept though'. Relatively short, you could beat this game in 4 hours if you tried. Although, it does take some getting used to.My final thoughts on the story of the game: Creations through observation.(Get it on sale though $10 is a reasonable price point I'd say)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												My favorite author is H.P. Lovecraft, so I make a point of checking out every game or movie that claims to be inspired by his work.  Usually the end result is pretty weak sauce, but sometimes I find epic experiences like Eternal Darkness or Dark Corners of the Earth ... or shorter, but still powerful stories like Ethan Carter.The game's story is more in line with Lovecraft's early work, with the focus on internalized existential angst with a smattering of references to the wider mythos and the power of dreams.  It's a slower, more personal, self-contained story, rather than one about ancient aliens rising up from terrible slumber to end humanity, which is fine.  Gameplay is all about investigating a series of murders in the gorgeously rendered Red Creek Valley while searching for Ethan Carter.  There is no combat and no way to die (although there is a gamebreaking bug that I at first mistook for character death towards the end, if you solve one of the puzzles before the final murder, that requires you to close the game and continue from the previous save).The unique method of sensing the psychic residue of strong emotions and reconstructing the timelines of the murders is clever and provides the only real "action" to what is primarily a short story you get to walk through and witness.  There are no outcomes to change, no secret endings, no agency for you as a player at all, really, other than the order in which you solve the murders.Graphically, the game is beautiful, alternating between peaceful and creepy, as needed.  The environments look and sound real and are the key to the experience.  Lesser visuals would have hurt the immersion.  The character models are less impressive by comparison, but the voice acting makes up for that and provides some believable personalities.  I would recommend you disable Motion Blur in the Graphics options, as I found it nauseating and a distraction from the great artwork done for the game.Total game time, exploring every possible location is 4-5 hrs, and for an $8 game, I can't really complain.  I pay more than that to see a 2 hr movie at the theatre.  Replayability is practically nil, however.  Once you have solved a murder or puzzle the hard way (without a guide - using one will only hurt your experience in the long run), you can easily burn through it again without much effort, further cutting down the game time to less than 2 hrs, easily, accounting for walking time and watching the cutscenes.  You'd be better off introducing someone else to the game, rather than play through it multiple times.  Then you could discuss the ending!For an additional $4, you can get a digital map, poster, making of document, and the origianl soundtrack, which I purchased to support the developers and found worth it for the great atmospheric music alone.If you want to experience a beautiful visual tale of mystery and the occult in the vein of H.P. Lovecraft, there's hardly a better way to spend a lazy afternoon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Jaw-droppingly beautiful. Incredibly original concept. Why cant all games look this good (and run flawlessly)? For being Mystery genre, with puzzle aspects, and full atmospheric immersion, its a total slam dunk in every category you can place it in. The devs of this game need to teach Techland how to create their map for Dying Light. (I know, I know, a city is mych different to render than a forest...dont leave stupid comments)One thing that amazes me is that so many games are trying to stand out by being "open world". Yet, take a game like Ethan Carter, and you realize that you dont need an open world environment to be good. Thoughtful writing creatives a narrative. Situations are revealed through the narrative, supported by the visual environment, and you have the basis of immersion. Open world or not, if you cant do at least one of those things well in a fpd style game, then it sucks. Ethan Carter not only does the basics right, but it does everything right.I fully expected a game this beautiful to not run smoothly. OR I expected to have to turn the settings down. It runs smoother than any game I have yet played. And I can run it at default settings (which are high by default) or even tweak it all the way up on the few options that are set moderately, and it still runs just as smooth.So far, I cant think of any area where this game falls short. It seems to excel in every category. And everywhere else it redefines quality and hopefully raises the bar for all other devs moving forward.Its easily a 10/10 - Buy itPS: Have I ever given a game a 10/10 before? And this isnt even my favorite type of game either

Posted: February 10, 2015
												Short answer - Would reccomend, 8.5/10, about 4 hours to play through.Longer review - Most games like this are not for everyone - short but sweet, atmospheric and spooky but without jump scares like the normal horror fan is used to. However, even if you like games that are action-packed and filled with nothing but cause and effect, taking some time to fall in love with this game will offer you a very rare and special singleplayer experience. Although many other games offer rich story and even more content, this game seems to succeed much more, for me, in capturing you in its Lovecraftian universe. Overall, I certainly reccomend you pick this up if you need a short break from traditional and more popular action based games. Its $20 price tag is well worth the wonderful experience, but you can often catch it on sale if you're low on Steam money. So if you're ready to spend about 4 or so hours to get caught up in the world of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, I reccomend it. Out of 10 I'd give it a solid 8.5, and hope you have just as much fun as I had with this game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												I've just played this through and I loved every minute.This is an open world puzzle game with an intriguing mystery storyline with horror elements. You take the role of a detective investigating the titular disappearance of a young boy, Ethan Carter. It's pretty hard to discuss the narrative further without giving away spoilers. It has been described as Lovecraftian, I would say there are a few nods to Lovecraft and the Cthulhu Mythos, but it's not the basis of the whole story.The puzzles are logical and not too tough to solve once you understand the mechanic. I did feel that the later murders were a little easier to solve and felt like less work had been put into them compared to say the first one. The puzzles are not all the same though, and there is a good variety to keep the player interested. I would suggest avoiding checking walkthroughs or guides as the puzzles are all achievable with a bit of thought. The graphics are stunning, the level of detail is very high and it must have taken a huge amount of work to create the game world. Pretty much everywhere you look there are amazing views and the landscape is very serene and peaceful. There is a known issue of flashing red lights in the trees which affects Radeon cards, and I did observe it but it wasn't frequent enough to cause a distraction.A few people have complained about the length of this game. You can expect 5-7 hours of gameplay depending on how good you are at solving the puzzles. I personally think that is pretty reasonable. I'd much rather have 6 hours of quality gameplay than 12 hours of filler.Anyway, I'm definitely recommending this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Incredible, breathtaking visuals enabled by creative use of photogrammetry and loving, meticulous artistic work. The amount of effort that went into crafting every meter of the world here is unmatched even by the best triple-A teams working on budgets orders of magnitude bigger. This is a masterpiece in environment art, an example to study. I definitely recommend reading the development blogs of the project for the look into the process - lots of developers should learn from this game.This carefully crafted environment is not there to be a passive eye candy either - it's an irreplaceable tool for telling the story. It sets the mood, manipulates your expectations and carefully directs your progression through the story. I'm not really sure what can be done to improve the game, actually. It's a complete, well-executed, focused product. There is no need for more action, the peaceful walks at your own pace are the definitive way to go through the experience - there is no place for explosions, crowds or thrilling chases here. There is no need for bigger environment - you don't need rock climbing, wing suits, boats and additional ten kilometers of lush forest to tell this story. There is no need for weapons, for inventory, for HUD.The sound work deserves high praise too - the environment is brought to life through masterful use of ambient, and the music is brilliant. So yeah, can definitely recommend this. Even if you prefer more active genres, this is a game is worth supporting - it represents the work attitude, fascination with art and understanding of narratives that I would love to see more in the game development industry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Visually this game is utterly fantastic. I have rarely had the joy of seeing a game with as much attention to detail placed into nearly every environmental element. Everything from houses through to trees and down to rocks on the ground combine to produce a wonderfully immersive and beautiful world to explore. On top of the technical prowess the game displays, there is a clear and very effective aesthetic which together with the graphical fidelity generate something truly beautiful. The lighting and scene setting are also expertly done and there were many times where I simply stopped to admire what had been done. At the same time as being beautiful to look at, it managed to convey a feeling of sadness, abandonment and menace that stuck with me throughout the whole game.The soundtrack and sound design fit in with the visuals perfectly, very soft and low key. The environmental sounds were subtle and were effective in grounding the player in the scene and were very immersive. In terms of gameplay, this game shares a lot of DNA with titles like Dear Esther and Gone Home in that it is mostly about exploration and has no action to speak of. Because of this, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is not something that everyone will like, however I do think it is one of the best entries I have played in this genre. You play as a supernatural detective called Paul Prospero who has come to a quiet backwater town in response to a letter from Ethan Carter, something terrible has happened in this quiet and near abandoned town and it is down to you to investigate it. I will keep away from discussing plot points so as not to spoil the story as the game does rely somewhat on the player gradually unveiling what happened.With Prospero‚Äôs medium like abilities, he is able to pick up an imprint of dramatic events that have occurred in an area ‚Äì however it is sensitive to disorder, and to get a clear picture, he needs to find objects that played a vital role within the event and try arrange them as they were prior to the event to reset the area.  From here he gets an impression of events and once you have figured what order they go in, you can then see the ghostly playback of what happened.These puzzles range in their effectiveness, with some being decidedly pedestrian in their difficulty, and one or two being very obscure. All however are quite effective in telling the story and for the most part they strike a good balance between pacing and difficulty. Each of these story fragments form up the story of what happened in this town, and although some of the puzzles can be done out of order, the major plot points are cleverly obscured until it is appropriate, which helps ensure the player does not get lost, while still allowing flexibility in how you reveal the story for the most part. The story was interesting and compelling enough to keep me going through till the end. Whilst the ending wasn‚Äôt quite what I had expected it was I felt a perfect ending for the narrative one that fit the tone that had permeated every aspect of the game. Like Dear Esther and Gone Home, this game is very short and does not lend itself to being very replayable. That said I think the length was appropriate. It didn‚Äôt feel stretched out and I think a longer play time would be detrimental to the experience. Dear Esther I felt was a dense poem ripe for critical analysis, Gone Home was a slice of life short story. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter I also feel is a short story in game form, a mystery novella. One that provided me with a great experience, well worth playing through.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great example of what a game can be based on nothing but environment and story elements. It uses far-reaching landscapes and beautiful visual effects to bring you a great narrative experience. However, be warned, this game may not be for those of little patience.__________Synopsis:You play as Paul Prospero, who seems to be a detective with paranormal abilities such as ESP. Receiving a letter from Ethan Carter, he learns Ethan has strong psychic connections, and that he has gone missing. Your job is to explore the village of Red Creek Valley and find Ethan. You quickly learn that something is amiss; the town is abandoned, no sign of Ethan's family, and mysterious occurrences. Story: A short, but interesting tale shrouded in mystery. Perhaps too short, depending on how quickly you progress through the game. It doesn't suffer very much from ups and downs in the story, and it ends pretty well too. Graphics: One of the most visually appealing games I've played in a long time. A wider, open world gives you plenty of room to stretch your legs and explore, taking in the sights and sounds as you go along. Functionality: Controls are pretty linear and simple. Essentially a Sherlock Holmes-puzzle solving game. Pick stuff up, find where it goes, and solve problems. Gameplay: Overall, it's not good. Again, it's basically a point-and-click mystery game akin to Sherlock Holmes. There is no combat mechanics, and every item falls into the one-use category. The real problem I encountered was spending obnoxiously long amounts of time searching the vast landscape for potential clues, which a majority of them felt arbitrary. This is where those of little patience may find the game frustrating.______________________________At the end of the day, you're buying this game for the story and the experience; but the experience tends to fall short when you're slowly crawling over a couple acres of land looking for that one last piece of the puzzle. I feel this may have been a better release under a different venue, like Heavy Rain, which offers great atmosphere, narritive, and incorporates at least DECENT gameplay elements. I did enjoy it, but my advice would be to wait until this game goes on sale to purchase.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												This game is visually stunning, atmospheric, captivating, and intriguing. There is little to nothing in the way of action, and overall it plays more like a mystery or puzzle game than survival horror (though it has those elements as well). If you're looking for a shooter, or a fast-paced pulse pounding survival horror game, this isn't it.It is, however, a masterfully executed, immersive, narrative experience reminiscent of Twin Peaks and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. The ways the player is given to interact with the environment and the story are both novel and intuitive, and the game has an unintrusive, minimal interface that fits well with the tone and theme of the game.I've been seeing this game compared to Dear Esther, which is a game I hate. Apart from generally seeming to have been constructed with more care, this game differs from Dear Esther in one very important, fundamental way: It gives the player things to do, and makes them feel like they are involved in the story. I felt a need to address this because the frequent comparisons between the two had caused me to avoid The Vanishing of Ethan Carter for quite some time. When I finally played it I was pleasantly surprised to find that this comparison does not hold up under scrutiny.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												What can I say about Ethan Carter without spoiling it's story? Not a lot other than: I really, REALLY liked it. It's easily one of the most athmospheric and beautiful games I've ever played. The setting, the tone, the influences, the story, the puzzles, everything just worked for me. As I said, I don't want to spoil anything about it, as I think this is one of the games you should come in as freash as you can be, with as little knowledge of it as possible. It's not a long game, but it also don't have any filler material, only quality stuff. And it's a top experience from start to finish because of that. I think this is also one of the games, that could've been easily messed up, if this would've been some AAA-retail game with 20 hours of content. I really think the lenght is perfect as it is.If I would have to suggest something, that IMO would've maybe made the game even better, it's probably: few more puzzles would have fitted in, eventhough there are some secrets also.Only real critique I had with the game is it's saving system: if you have some mystery in the middle of solving and you go and do something and see the "Saving scene...", which usually leads you to believe, that everything you've done/found so far is saved, it doesn't save the mystery that is in the middle of solving. So, just a tip: solve all the mysteries you start before quitting, so you'll avoid playing things thru all over again.All in all this game is a hell of a debut from the small team hailing from Poland - The Astronauts. And if they'll do more of these narrative game experiences in the future, it'll be a day 1 buy for me. I'm really looking forward what they'll decide to do next.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Beginning with a pointedly vague premise of your being some kind of detective on the trail of the titular missing child, the game barely holds your hand as you discover your paranormal investigative abilities and begin to piece together a series of strange events in a remote countryside. That lack of hand holding is more a part of the gameplay than one might initially realize as it ultimately provokes a sort of trial and error process that is in itself an investigation. Despite a few fairly simple puzzles, the game is mostly about discovery. While primarily linear, there are various clues and revelations lying just off the beaten path, many of which ultimately need to be discovered to complete the game, but that (whether found later or during the course of your primary investigation) don‚Äôt stymie the pace of the game.The game‚Äôs visuals are excellent, featuring not only the river valley vistas seen in the early part of the game, but beautifully dilapidated interiors and dank caves as well. The audio as well is great, with a near perfect score, quality voice acting, and immersive environmental sound. The GUI overlays are brilliant and are realized in such a manner as not feel like an interface, but instead like an extension of the protagonist‚Äôs investigative abilities. The ultimate result is a greater sense of immersion and that is a large part of Ethan Carter‚Äôs triumph.Throughout the nearly four hours I spent with The Vanishing of Ethan Carter I was almost completely enraptured by it, spurred on both by a sense of wonderment at the world before my eyes and also by a drive to discover the truth of the mystery at hand. It‚Äôs difficult to talk about the story at all without spoiling anything except to say that even when predictable, Ethan Carter delivers with a compelling emotional gravitas. I honestly can‚Äôt recommend this game enough to fans of first person adventure games, especially Amenisia, Gone Home, or Dear Esther. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is worth picking up at any price.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I'm finding it difficult to make my mind up about this game.  When I saw the trailers I thought "Hmmm, what a lovely looking game" and that held true.  Graphically, this game is top notch.  However, it is a little discordant: although supposedly set in some small town (presumably) in the US, the architecture and landscape are quintessentially mid-east European (think eastern Austria, Czech. Republic etc. and you get the idea).The gameplay itself is quite linear in a meandering sort of a way so you are free to do as you wish within limits; if you don't complete some tasks then others will not become available.  The puzzles are reasonably challenging without being blockers - a little bit of logic will get you a long way in this game.  The storyline is really what is making me waver.  OK, I know it's a supernatural, horror type thing but it isn't an "omg, what the heck just jumped outta the walls at me" frighty game - it's more HP Lovecraft: dark, foreboding and, at times, rather depressing.  I've never been a fan of HP Lovecraft.  I don't want to say much more than that otherwise it will spoil things.In short, if you're a fan of old school adventure games, beautifully executed and with a reasonable level of challenge then you will most likely love this game.  Just don't expect to feel refreshed, invigorated and uplifted when you finish it :).

This is the type of game you want your non gaming friends to play because of how great it is.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												The game is a foray into something much more involved that doesn't hit the player until the end of the game, and the sequences in between are wonderful yet shocking-- in many different ways. The free form of the game may mean that you get lost initially, or miss a few things, but it will let you know at the end what you might have missed so you can go revisit it.This is one of the more colorful mixes of suspense, imagination and mystery that I've come across. The world is painstakingly handcrafted, with no sense of it being generated by a machine. I could easily stand at many different places in the game and screenshot away, and use the results for desktop wallpaper. And it's beautifully done enough that it might cause some to ask where it is.This game manages to strike several emotional chords throughout its six hours of gameplay, but for the price I think it's worth the trip. If you've considered picking up this game, I'd encourage you to do so.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, a narrative adventure game from The Astronauts, is a miracle of game storytelling. It redefines immersion and sets the bar for realistic simulation of the natural world astonishingly high‚Äîone could even say, excessively high.It tells a story about a young boy who appears to have vanished. The gameplay consists of an exploration of his world, uncovering and solving a number of mysteries about what appears to be happening.The game warns you that it will not be holding your hand, and, through the protagonist, that things are not at all what they seem. The task of the reviewer is impossibly difficult because no explanation of how true this turns out to be can be made without spoiling the experience.All I will say is this: welcome to the mind of a young boy.With most games, the game-play is what matters the most. With this kind of game, however, spoiling the story will spoil the game. It is similar to other story driven games like ‚ÄúPapo and Yo,‚Äù ‚ÄúBrothers, a Tale of Two Sons,‚Äù ‚ÄúGone Home,‚Äù and possibly also the Amnesia games (particularly the second of those). Although the visual style has drawn comparisons to ‚ÄúDear Esther,‚Äù the games are only superficially similar. In "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" one is very much a participant in events.The game world is breathtakingly lavish and beautiful. For a small game, a massive effort at realism has been undertaken, and it succeeds wildly. If you've seen the game (not just screenshots) than you know that my praise is not excessive. Frankly, the story would have stood up well with a far less demanding art style. Yet they brought it off brilliantly.Like many adventure-story games, there are puzzles to solve (several of these are quite entertaining and clever; have a pen and paper handy), items to locate and put in their proper places, narrative chronologies to determine, locations to discover. The process of uncovering clues and discovering meaning is not difficult, yet the tasks are varied and interesting. The game is not a long one (I stretched it to more than six hours).However, this game integrates game-play and storytelling better than any game I‚Äôve seen. Everything has a reason‚Äîeven the fact that despite the realism of the world you‚Äôre exploring, the sun never moves in the sky. Everything is seamless and utterly engaging.None of this would mean anything if it weren‚Äôt for the fact that, as the game progressed and the boy‚Äôs family situation became more and more clear, I found myself caring about him as if he were my own son. As Prospero the detective, I became dedicated to finding him, to helping him out of whatever desperate situation he found himself in. And the truth, revealed at last, is moving and satisfying as narrative in a way that few games have achieved. I've read novels that were less satisfying than the story in this game. Think about that a minute. I‚Äôve got to salute the developer team for performing a miracle: they have created a story that is told in a completely believable world that could not be told in another medium.The game is not without its flaws, the principal one being the auto-save system. The game encourages you to explore, and when you uncover the solution to one of the many mysteries, the solved state of that mystery is saved. Each successive ‚Äúscene‚Äù is saved along with the others as you discover them. However, when you quit the game and return later, any scene that you‚Äôve begun but not finished will revert to its ‚Äúundiscovered‚Äù status. This is annoying until you realize what is happening; if you don‚Äôt get it quickly‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt‚Äîyou can potentially lose hours of wandering about. The game is a luscious world that begs you to wander about. Just realize that once you discover a clue, that means (generally) that there are other clues nearby, and that you need to find them all and complete that story segment before you can safely leave the game. It is true that the clues are generally in the same locations, so this is not difficult, but it helps to be forewarned.There are also minor inconsistencies (in the version that I finished, it is possible to have two trains at once in the mine‚Ä¶), buttons that don‚Äôt seem to work properly the first time you press them, and other minor graphic glitches.But none of these, even the auto-save system, which the developer assures us would be impractical to change at this point, detract in the least bit from the game. Once you get into the rhythm of it, and have completed your first scene, things proceed very smoothly.Gamers who liked the games I mentioned earlier, or other story-driven but non-passive games will enjoy ‚ÄúThe Vanishing of Ethan Carter.‚Äù The art design is best-in-class. The original musical score is haunting and beautiful, and is still playing in my head.Bravo, Astronauts. Thanks for the wonderful story. I‚Äôm looking forward to your next project.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												This game is more or less:10% Myst20% Dear Esther20% Gone Home50% Lovecraftian Horror MysteryNow the (non-spoilery) review:Let me begin by saying this game is right up my alley so I may be slightly biased in the positive direction. Graphics: This game is beautiful, and not just because of the extremely high quality visuals. This game does a better job using high fidelity graphics and environment design to create a deep sense of immersion and an engrossing atmosphere than any I've played in recent years except perhaps The Last of Us. The wind, weather effects, lighting, textures, richly detailed and expertly designed environments all work together perfectly to create an eerie, atmospheric and very "real" feeling world. 10/10Gameplay Design: Engaging mechanics of play isn't the reason to play this kind of game. For a game that claims to "not do any hand holding" most of the puzzles are‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•easy, although some of them are pretty original and well executed. Other than that exploring semi-linear environments is the only way you directly interact with the games world. However it is a perfectly sufficient manner to get you through the primary draw of the game; the story and environment . 6.5/10Environment(lvl) Design: This is where the game really shines. I don't think I've ever played a game where the world felt so real. The placement of every rock, log, patch of grass, door, etc. is perfect, and the environments are detailed without feeling "over done". The visual reference point I keep coming back to is The Last of Us but while it was a beautiful game with excellent visual design the world did feel stylized. Ethan Carter on the other hand has many areas that feel like places I've actually been, so close in fact that it should be uncanny, but instead it just adds a whole other level of immersion and engagement, especially when they introduce supernatural elements.Specific praises include: How well they use visual highlighting to guide the player to places of interest (including both actual light, and the shape of the landscape). Excellent use of the outdoor environment to hide the borders of the levels, this place only has a few places that are straight up "invisible walls" but you only bump into them if you're doing things that don't make sense in the context of the game, and the word is so beautifully realized and expertly designed that you forget about them the minute you step back onto the path the game intends you to take. It guides you without it feeling like it's shoving you down a hallway, something that is incredibly difficult to do. 10/10 Story: It's pretty difficult to critique the story it in detail without spoiling it, but here goes. It's well presented, and it starts out very intriguing but I called the twist ending about a third of the way through and it's pretty steeped in the tropes of supernatural mystery. It's not terribly original, but the way you experience the story is novel and engaging enough to elevate it past the written words. 8/10Overall Experience: The game won't change the way you think about games, and it isn't quite as gut wrenching or mind bending as other similar games, but if you enjoy games like the only I likened it to, give it a look. It's beautiful, atmospheric, and genuinely intriguing and engaging (while you're playing it, once you have the full picture it loses some of it's magic).One last praise I had is how well it paces itself, and how it maintains an atmosphere of mystery and subtle horror without every being terrifying the way something like Outlast, or even Amnesia is. There where many times it could have taken a turn and thrown in a jump scare, or a tense stealth/chase sequence, but it choose to instead be morose, bittersweet, and contemplative, and I think the game is better for it. 8/10Bottom Line: 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Let's start off with the good side of things. The graphics, in short, are the best you can witness at this point in time. It is really a stunning looking game. I'm really surprised I can't actually smell the environment through my screen because it looks so beautiful. 10/10 - This really sets a bar, and simply needs to be experienced to be believed.Sound design is also exceptional. All the music and other auditory cues are timed very well and create a good atmosphere. I do feel that a lot of games get this right, though. Having played other games where atmosphere is important, I think developers realize that you just can't build a good immersive game without the proper auditory cues. This game makes great use of its music, sound effects, and just absolute, dead silence whenever necessary. It creates a very eerie atmosphere indeed.The story is very intriguing itself. It's got a nice, Bioshock level twist at the end. I do have to say that I expected this game to be a bit more focused on the "horror" aspect, and I found the story undermines it a little bit. It's hard to explain this without actually spoiling the story, but needless to say, I felt fairly confident that I'm unlikely to be in any actual threat, or at least the threats are going to be rather infrequent. It's not a bad story, though, in fact quite the contrary, it's a good story told very well. It just happens to miss the theme that I was expecting from the game. It's still very chilling as it progresses. It's just that you as a character are not participating in it, just observing it.Now on with the negatives.Steam will show that my play time for this game is about 3 hours or so. That's how long it really took to get through this game. Why is it so short? It makes it feel more like a minigame than a full fledged title. This short play time really makes me wish that the developers actually cut down some of the time they spent on the graphics and sunk more of it into creating an actual game. Pretty graphics are all well, but I want a good game.And that's another thing. This game can well be called an Eerie Walking Simulator. It's very minimalistic in almost all content that actually matters. It's a great experience, but it's so hard to actually call this a game. I think I would have felt no shame in just watching someone play it on youtube. It would spare me some of the backtracking if I just happened to miss one of the puzzles in the world, having to go back to it just to unlock the final narrative. I do like the fact that no one is holding your hand, however, and the fact that the world is, for the most part, open even if there is little of it.Overall, the experience is great, and the quality of execution is superb, but because of that, quantity suffers greatly. At 3-5 hours, you can easily finish it in one sitting even if you take your time to explore the environment. I'll recommend the game, but only if its on sale. I give it 7/10, just because of its length and the small amount of stuff to do in it. Despite the shortness, it's got a great story, great graphics, and great sound. If you can't get it on sale, watch it somewhere on youtube because it's worth at least that much.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												This game is absolutely by far the best showcase for the dated Unreal Engine 3, so much so that I still have a hard time believing it really is using it. It really is astonishingly good-looking (honestly, you really have to see it to believe it) with excellent textures and almost photo-realistic landscapes and water and some lovely lighting effects. I was frequently stopping to admire the scenery.As for the game, it's an interesting variation on the concept of wandering around exploring rather than combat or action (the so-called "walking simulator" like Dear Esther or Gone Home) but with some nifty puzzles that once completed reveal more of the story. Unfortunately, if the game has any faults it is that the lack of any kind of hand-holding or tutorials at the start led me to being confused as to what I was actually supposed to be doing. And because the game is not linear and I was exploring rather than solving the puzzles then I found that my progress was not being saved (the game only saved on completion of puzzles rather than at specific points on the map, though this may have changed now with newer patches).Despite that, which may not be an issue for others, this is a very unusual, beautiful and relaxing game to play so it is hard not to recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Let's get this out of the way: this is a narrative-and-exploration-driven game. This is a downside for some people. Personally, I enjoy these games. This is, in my opinion, the ultimate of these games  out there. At least, the popular ones. I am sure someone who is more into these games than I am could rattle off a list of games that do this concept better.For me, Vanishing Ethan's Carter is a combination of an intriguing story, great visuals, great audio, interesting gameplay and novel mechanics. The biggest strength is clearly the game's visuals. The environements are incredible, high-res, and realistic. I cannot think of a time when I could even see tiling or repeating textures. Along with them, the sound design is great. The ambient noise and music lends a great atmospheric nature to the game.Another strength for me is the mechanics. The "put the scene in order" game is fun and novel, although sometimes difficult to understand why a part of a scene is represented by an object or in a location when, sometimes, that object or location is never seen in the final cinematic.The weakness in Carter's Vanishing Ethan is really more of a weak strength: the story. Don't get me wrong, it has several good twists. The problem I have is that it's confusing, particularly near the end. It feels like we needed a final "put all the cinematics in order" game to make sure I had the timeline right. Then there's the final twist which seems almost like a cop-out to me, but it has a lot of symbolism so it kind of gets away with it.Overall, this game is well-worth the money you put into it. If you enjoy exploration games, you will probably enjoy this. If you don't, consider getting it during a sale!

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
A Paladin‚Äôs Steam Review: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. A Subtly Disturbing Yet Compelling Mystery Game.Genre: First Person Atmospheric Story Driven Mystery with Psychological Horror ElementsDeveloper & Publisher: The AstronautsPlatform Support: Windows, PS4. Mac & Linux "Coming Soon". Business Model: Base Game. Copy Purchased by MyselfOverall Gameplay ThoughtsVanishing comes very, very close to a Walking Simulator. There really isn‚Äôt a failure state, your actions don‚Äôt really affect the game in any meaningful way and the game expects you to experience a lot of it. The only influence you have is exploring the world of Red Creek Valley, solving the puzzles and, by extension, the mystery Paul Prospero is here to solve. Oh right, that‚Äôs the guy who you‚Äôre controlling and hear monologue as you explore the valley. So, you'll walk along at a fairly steady pace (there's a reasonably faster sprint as well), drink in the atmosphere while you search for clues of Ethan's whereabouts. All the while discovering that there's something creepy and sinister beneath the surface. Red Creek Valley is divided up into multiple areas, each containing a major puzzle or two for you to solve. Puzzles, for the most part, boil down to finding all the objects within a given area and figuring out how they all go together. The music playing in the background will clue you in on whether you‚Äôve left the given area very subtly. Which is helpful because you‚Äôll never need to leave an area in order to solve that particular puzzle. There aren‚Äôt any random items on the other side of the map that you have to find. It should be noted that it isn't required to solve these puzzle areas in any particular order, they can be done at any time. Outside of soaking in the sights and experiencing the strange events going on, there‚Äôs not much else to do. However, I always felt like I was involved. There wasn't any boring section I felt forced to walk through. It might help that Red Creek Valley appealed to me. Being able to see the burned out buildings, the rusted train cars and nature reclaiming the area, it really intrigued me. It's a feel of history and decay that Vanishing goes out of its way to really sell to the player. It feels like a real place and it‚Äôs setup like a real place. I think that helped me enjoy the game more. Atmosphere & JumpscaresThe atmosphere ate away at me. Slowly, creepily, I would sometimes jump at my phone beeping at me. It‚Äôs insidious how this game gets into your head. It makes you think something will jump out, scare you half to death and eat what remains of your sanity alive. Spoiler: that doesn‚Äôt happen. Except for one area, I‚Äôll explain below. This isn‚Äôt a hardcore scare title like Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It‚Äôs far tamer by comparison while holding its own. I was often thinking that some dark fantasy creature such as Cthulhu was behind the scenes. It was amusing when that theory was half confirmed. The game will do its best to unnerve you. So long as you let it. There‚Äôs only one section of the map where jump scares are present. It‚Äôs in a mine and they sort of warn you that it‚Äôs coming. Sort of. And it‚Äôs mostly optional unless you want a 100% completion rating. At least, I‚Äôm fairly certain its optional. The scare is when you‚Äôre running around in a mining maze, searching for clues to open a large door in the center of it. In this area, is an undead miner who‚Äôs been cursed. While you‚Äôre walking around, if you hear a telltale noise you should immediately turn around and go the other way. Otherwise, BOO. You have to start from the beginning of the maze. PC Settings & OptimizationOptimization wise, this game leaves a bit to be desired. You will need to tweak your graphics options to get the best performance as running everything on high will drag the performance down hard. I noticed that Anti-Aliasing and Texture Filtering were the big performance hogs. Oh and there is constant texture loading, which will cause your game to ‚Äústutter‚Äù frequently as it loads them. This is a problem that affects a lot of computers and it‚Äôs immersion breaking. Additionally, if you‚Äôre not running a 16:9 resolution, the game will letterbox/pillarbox. Which I find to be frankly inexcusable for a native PC game to be this way. I can‚Äôt figure out why the devs didn‚Äôt scale the resolutions properly, it‚Äôs not like the Unreal engine can‚Äôt do it. PCGamingWiki has a installable solution to fix this as well as grant you multi-monitor and ultra-widescreen options. Additionally, while there is a proper Field-of-View slider in the options, (70-120) it crops the image in order to do it. Overall, while the game does run/scale well (and it does so long as you tweak about in the settings), the remaining problems are less excusable. Also, saving is only done in chunks so you might revert some of your actions when quitting and reloading. Redux Edition Quick ThoughtsI gave the Redux edition a quick run through and they seem to have fixed a lot of the problems the original game had. The micro-stutter is completely gone, there's no more pillarboxing as the resolution scales and performance generally seems to be better, if more taxing on machines. Saving is now done every time you act now too. FoV is still a crop effect but I'll let it be. There's also a bunch of tweaks and visual improvements added that you probably won't notice. There's no story difference between the two editions so if you can, play the redux. If that's too taxing, play the original. Kudos to the devs for doing this for free. Final ThoughtsThe atmosphere and mystery makes for a compelling experience. While it does have a lot of adventure/walking simulator aspects to it, it still keeps the player involved the entire time. The atmosphere of a decaying rural area known as Red River Valley is simply intriguing. The psychological horror just works so well. Jump scares are rare but there‚Äôs something that eats at you the entire time. When finished, the game will leave you with more questions than answers though not in the ‚Äúfind out in the sequel‚Äù sort of way. I should note that the characters are rather cliche but when I consider the ending, it works and feels intentional. Visually, the game looks superb and the audio is top notch. If you're looking for a fun mystery/exploration through a decaying rural area, give The Vanishing of Ethan Carter a go.Read This and More Like It on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												An entertaining mystery/adventure game with a compelling narrative and striking visuals.You play Paul Prospero, the Philip Marlowe of the supernatural world, picking up one last case after receiving a letter from fellow mystic and absent-minded storyteller, the boy, Ethan Carter. He's vanished, so it's time to put that second-sight to use and track him down!Graphically the game is quite stunning, and when combined with an eerie and ominous score, lends itself to a genuine Lovecraftian atmosphere. There are moments where you may inexplicably look behind you.The puzzles aren't anything to write home about, and I thought, could have been more challenging, but they will immerse you in the story. The narrative is well paced, at no point did trudge on to the next scene wondering what I was doing. It felt as though I had sufficiently adventured by the time I reached the ending, which is certainly worth it, bringing your supernatural connection to the young Ethan Carver full circle.The whole thing will take about four hours, a little more if you go achievement hunting.Have fun!9/10

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												This game is absolutely by far the best showcase for the dated Unreal Engine 3, so much so that I still have a hard time believing it really is using it. It really is astonishingly good-looking (honestly, you really have to see it to believe it) with excellent textures and almost photo-realistic landscapes and water and some lovely lighting effects. I was frequently stopping to admire the scenery.As for the game, it's an interesting variation on the concept of wandering around exploring rather than combat or action (the so-called "walking simulator" like Dear Esther or Gone Home) but with some nifty puzzles that once completed reveal more of the story. Unfortunately, if the game has any faults it is that the lack of any kind of hand-holding or tutorials at the start led me to being confused as to what I was actually supposed to be doing. And because the game is not linear and I was exploring rather than solving the puzzles then I found that my progress was not being saved (the game only saved on completion of puzzles rather than at specific points on the map, though this may have changed now with newer patches).Despite that, which may not be an issue for others, this is a very unusual, beautiful and relaxing game to play so it is hard not to recommend it.
