number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												On the plus side, the game looks gorgeous, sounds beautiful, and is very well voice acted.  I won't elaborate on these, other than to say - look at those screenshots, they aren't lying.  I also like the investigative aspect; I appreciate games featuring detective player avatars ... that can actually detect their way out of a paper bag - Paul looks at evidence and actually comes to intelligent conclusions about what happened!  On the negative side, it was short, yet went on too long.  You can't beat the game without finding and solving everything.  Yes, finding, and some of the plot scenes are decently hard to find.  You can either (as I did) consult a guide, or play hunt-the-pixel in a 3d world.  Also, the investigations sometimes involve the same problem, hunting for all the hotspots in order to progress. I also take issue with the plot.  Basically, it isn't very scary.  Ethan Carter doesn't build tension well because the pacing is off.  You yourself are never in danger at all, so any tension would theoretically revolve around either a rush to save Ethan, or a burning drive to know what happened.  The problem is you barely get to know any of the characters, or see anything about their world, so it's hard to get drawn in that way.  The net effect is a moody story, but not really a very scary one.  Also, I did not really like certain spoileriffic aspects of the ending.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is the debut title from Polish developer The Astronauts founded by former People Can Fly (Painkiller, Bulletstorm) founder Adrian Chmielarz. As an adventure game with an emphasis on exploration and atmosphere without any combat whatsoever, it‚Äôs definitely a departure for the designer. The players assume the role of Paul Prospero, a detective with paranormal abilities who comes to picturesque Red Creek Valley after receiving a letter from a young boy named Ethan Carter. It is clear from the beginning that Ethan is missing, but everything else is up to you to uncover. There is no tutorial, there is no hand holding.The most striking thing about the game from the first second is how gorgeous it looks. You start off in a dark patch of forest, but very soon you‚Äôll reach a bridge providing a breathtaking look at the valley. It makes a strong statement for realism and art being able to co-exist in a single beautiful package. The sense of scale is impressive as well. Even though in reality this is a fairly linear game, it is designed in such a way that it gives the illusion of grand scale. It masterfully escapes that ugly feeling that you‚Äôre being pushed down a singular narrow path. This is also reflected in the puzzles and storytelling. You can solve the puzzles in any order you wish and you‚Äôll probably even miss some as well as you go along. However, you need to solve them all if you wish to see the very ending.There are two types of puzzles: solving a murder and experiencing a supernatural short story written by Ethan that you can find wandering about. Solving a murder revolves around finding a body and several key items and then piecing together the chronology of events which will then unfold before you. It is a really interesting and effective method of storytelling that ensures that the player feels involved in what happened even though he is just an observer. Both the murders and Ethan‚Äôs stories give small yet interesting glimpses of insight into the relationships within the Carter family and the strange and tragic events which took place. The puzzles themselves are fairly simple and the narrative is light, but the sense of immersion and atmosphere is very strong throughout. I will also provide a small hint regarding the puzzles which may prevent you from wandering around aimlessly too much. Each puzzle is a separate scene, this means that all of the necessary items and solutions regarding the puzzle are nearby, you won‚Äôt find an item in one location that you will need to use somewhere else.The terrific soundtrack and sound design are also a big part of the great immersion and atmosphere. A haunting piano melody or the soft rustling of leaves in the wind go a long way to establish a sense of presence, you really feel like you‚Äôre there yourself. It‚Äôs a game of contrasts. Beautiful and serene in one moment, creepy and uneasy in the second. You‚Äôre trekking through an idyllic landscape only to uncover abandoned, dilapidated buildings and mutilated bodies. And it all comes together in a refreshingly unexpected ending that will give you pause and provide you with something to think about even if for only a moment.The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a truly great adventure game with a fantastically realized game world brimming with clever design that will keep you motivated to uncover the secrets it hides.8 OUT OF 10 (GREAT)

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												When it comes to me and my relationship with video games, Point & Click genre games are my main one. They speak to me the most, fit my personality the most, are the ones I have the best mind for, and a pretty good one at that, at least I believe. It was while I was seeing if it was plausible to get a twitch streamer I use to watch to play a fav of mine, that one or two other watchers said in the chat that this game was the new hot point & click game to play. I prefer my point & click games to be ones where you socialize. Ones where you talk to people and are immediately told where you are and what the deal is. So I was off put at first that this game doesn't do either of those things. You're completely lost, isolated, and don't know where you are, and no one is around. It's a game where you're supposed to feel lonely. Since I suffer from chronic depression IRL, partly caused by loneliness, I really disliked at first this aspect. After the second attempt to play this is when I got successfully hooked.I hate the gamer mentality of "I dub this game really good at being pretty, beautiful, and atmospheric, RIGHT NOW AS SOON I'M STARTING IT!" It's pretentious, and puts pressure on people thinking of playing the game to display as much "good behavior" pretension. I say no, it's better to be an "a**hole", and appreciate the beauty and atmosphere, IDK, when your on your flippin' death bed, as long as it's after playing the game for a nice long time/well after you've finished it. I don't give an f when I first start it, no one deserves to get that much sucking up. It's better to never say the game is beautiful than to say it is at record speed.The memory I have of the feeling I got from the game after getting into it AFTER A GOOD WHILE OF PLAYING IT,  I liked quite a lot. That's what is suppose to happen. The key to games like this is suppose to be time, and a lot of it. I REMEMBER it being beautiful and atmospheric in a pretty solidly good way. It's mechanics and challenges took some getting use to, but they where pretty good too.My biggest complaint is the story. It's a good story up until the end. To keep this spoiler free, I'll keep it to just saying this: 60's and 70's folk music artists like Simon & Garfunkel, who sang regularly about how much it sucks to live in the big city and how they'd rather feel the earth beneath their feet, apparently where completely wrong according to whoever wrote this game. According to him, if you move out to the wilderness with your family, the adults you live with will apparently NOT WANT YOU to enjoy the earth beneath your feet. They rather you burn to death than experience the outside. So stop complaining and just shut up Simon & Garfunkel, the city is just fine to be trapped in. THAT DOESN'T MAKE ANY SENSE!!!!I recommend this game, just ignore to asinine writing toward the end.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Being a fan of games like Dear Ester, Gone Home, and the likes, I had very high hopes for this game. Alas my disappointment was big. Very.After several annoying bugs I finally got the game to work and was set for a few hours.The atmosphere Red Creek Valley sets is perfect. It looks beautiful, it sounds perfect and your goals and how to find them become clear soon enough.But then the flaws begin to trickle through.Red Creek Valley is big. Too big. All too soon you find yourself searching for a needle in a haystack.Oh, did you miss that? Well, better go back or you won't be able to finish the game!To me, that's not the game's disclaimer "not holding your hand", that's developers being to lazy to create something that makes sense as a whole. It's like a world with very few random interactive spots thrown around, to not distract you too much from their beautiful graphics simulator.And when you finally find something to keep you from falling asleep during those long hikes, it's equally boring and unintuitive. Puzzles, if you can call them that, are way to easy and are a mere distraction. And when you are backtracking a story you find yourself running around looking for items like a fool, in places these items would never be. Tedious.As far as the story itself, there are parts that are very creative, and made me regain my interests, and then there are parts that made me go: "Oh dear." Especially the ending, which, to be honest, turned an OK story into a pretty silly one.All in all, I would only recommend this game if you could get it in a sale, and want to run around in beautiful Red Creek Valley. Don't bother about the story, though, you'll just get annoyed.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												"The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" is a masterfully crafted and very beautiful game - but certainly not one for everybody.If you are looking for a game with tons of action, loads of weapons, and hundreds of tasks and missions, then "Ethan Carter" is not for you.There is almost no action, and there are no weapons. And there is actually very little to do, except following the story (which isn't always easy, as the game does not tell you where to go and what to do) and solving fairly easy puzzles.Also, it's quite short. I finished it in some 5 hours, without the help of any tutorials (but with the help of a friend).And still, for me, it is one of my absolute gaming highlights in 2014. The graphics are simply the best I've ever seen in a game, the story is masterfully crafted, and the end has me thinking about it long after I finished the game. Hats off to The Astronauts for this masterpiece.For everyone who sees computer games not just as entertainment, but also as an art form, "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" is a must-have, plain and simple.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												The atmosphere is great and the visual design is amongst the best I've seen, although this is not enough to carry this otherwise underwhelming game. You're thrown in the woods and left to figure stuff out by yourself. In principle this is great, except that the game still has you on a leash. An invisible leash, which translates into you to randomly go to places in the hope of triggering some progression. The little snippets of story you uncover are nice, and the first section of the game is consequently strong, yet falls quickly into a lull when you arrive to the main storyline which pretends to be deeper and more complex than it actually is, using the unreliable narrator scope and flashbacks to convey a very superficial story. Furthermore it makes no sense internally, how the first half of the game ties in with the latter. Wrapped up with underwhelming and repetitive gameplay, the game is an overall lackluster. As mentioned, you are to walk around the map looking for items and then place them in the correct spot. There are some guessing games in which you reconstruct the chronology of an event, and there is a horribly designed maze game. Story games can be amazing, and I'm amongst the ones who enjoyed the likes of Dear Esther and Gone Home. This game fails horribly in even being close to a decent narrative game.That being said, the visual design is top notch and the atmosphere is great. The map is well designed, interesting, and the landscape is pleasing. The music contributes greatly to the game, and gives it a somewhat eerie feel. Unfortunately the poor storyline drags the atmosphere down around the second part of the game. Altogether, I'm left feeling very unimpressed by this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												There is a phenomenon that when something is done too well, it fails to impress.I vacillated about whether to recommend this game, but I ultimately decided that my experience of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, unfortunately, is subject to that phenomenon. The Astronauts did a wonderful job with this game from a technical perspective, which is something everyone should support. The graphics are fantastic, the music hauntingly beautiful, and the voice-acting emotionally wrenching. That being said, the story is lacking and even the beautiful world doesn't give the game enough depth to make up for the weakness of the plot, particularly the ending. There was something about the world that just didn't draw me in--perhaps they walked the line between real and surreal so well that I was never convinced it was either. The ending is both twist and ambiguous, and I wasn't surprised by the twist and I hadn't been drawn in enough to care about the ambiguity. It just didn't leave a mark, positive or negative.After giving it some more reflection, (I‚Äôve updated this review) I can say that my problem with the plot of Ethan Carter is less a problem with this game itself (though I have given my complaints) and more likely a problem with the genre. To me exploration felt more like looking at a painting than actually stepping into a real world, and following the story felt more like checking off a list than solving a mystery.That I don't recommend The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is my statement that if I had the opportunity to do it over, I would have done something different--entered a different story in a different world if you will. But most importantly, I would have done something in a different format‚Äîlike reading a book‚Äîa clear indication of my dislike for the genre. I will be watching the future developments from The Astronauts and I do hope for another opportunity to play another game made with the same rare technical skill as this one.Bottom line: if you like walking simulators (and this is a bit more than just a walking simulator), get this one. If you are unsure of the genre, Ethan Carter is unlikely to change your mind.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												My girlfriend and I went through this game in one sitting, which took us about four hours. We used a walkthrough to guide us through portions of the game, so that might mean we lost an hour or two - but I don't feel that these additional hours would have been well spent. The biggest mistake this game makes is giving you repetitive searching and fetching tasks, some of which are just overly tedious and out of place in a game that is so focused on telling a story. I don't want to search for a little bloody rock hidden behind high leaves of grass to advance the plot or wander through a maze looking for five identical corpses so I can open a cryptic puzzle. No, this puzzling and combing of the vast landscape this game has to offer was not fun at all. The developers seem not to understand how to create gameplay that engages instead of distracting from the story. In a game that exists primarily to tell that story, I would actually expect less involved gameplay, so if I (as a "core" gamer of many genres) am faced with an attempt to challenge my gaming skills, I want this challenge to be fun and the opposite of tedious and grinding, but the latter is what this game offers and not much else besides the story.So is the STORY any good? Without spoiling anything, I have to say my girlfriend (who cares deeply about well-written stories) and I were both surprised at how it ended, but that ending made the whole endavour kind of pointless and just threw up more questions than answers. It's basically just a story of supernatural powers and multiple murders; you use the former to solve the latter nine times throughout this game, piecing together what happened to this Ethan Carter boy. But the end result just seems to invalidate it all and makes the supernatural aspect, which I highly disliked from the start, even more ambiguous.Dammit, if you write a story for a game soley to tell that story, then please make it a GOOD one that I can actually grasp and follow, and that is BELIEVABLE most of all! And if you start your game off saying "this game does not hold your hand" (which is rare these days and usually a good thing!), then make sure I understand how to play it because when I spend the first fifteen minutes wandering around aimlessly and have to consult a walkthrough to understand the mechanics, you've done something wrong by game design standards.I had heard only good things about this game and while I don't want to say that I regret the 10 bucks I paid for it on sale, I do wish that all the positive press and personal recommendations had actually held true in the end. I fail to see how so many people love the game when there is not much here that would make it that great.Pros:- well utilized Unreal Engine 3 with very convincing architecture and landscape- free roaming "open world" gameplay makes for great immersion- good music and convincing voice actingCons:- occasional stutters while otherwise perfectly fluid- puzzles are rarely easily apparent and require lots of searching/trial and error- story itself is not very good (personal preference) and illogical at times- this game is more of an artistic showcase than a well presented storyBuy if you liked Dear Esther and other more artsy, mysterious games that move away from traditional routes. Be prepared to do some tedious *very much traditional* puzzling and searching. Keep a guide handy to enjoy more of the actual story. Go in with low expectations.

There's no quick travel system of any kind until you get to the end of the game, and even then it's only one way travel.This game is not worth anywhere near full price, and it's not worth the sale price I bought it at (66% off).

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
The Vanishing is basically what happens when the developers of a visual novel decide to make stress on the 'visual' part. The game's surroundings are relatively small but almost any inch of the landscape can be a spot for a lovely screenshot. That part is adorable and the environment is very picturesque.Unlike many other visual novels, this one has a first-person view and freedom of action. It involves you into the game's world yet more. Seeing a path is one thing, walking it yourself is quite another. Moving around slowly and quietly, exploring, pondering over matters, watching for details that need attention - and that's all as if you were there. Nothing threatens you. Nothing disturbs you. You have all the time in the world to go where you want to go and see what you would like to see. My explorer's nature was deeply satisfied.The plot is curious. I won't say that it's entirely original - the basic idea around which all the events circle has already been seen in a certain game, - but it certainly doesn't mean that you will easily understand everything from the very first minute. There will be no instructions on where to go and what to do next, no maps, no journals with careful recordings of each step. If you want to rebuild the story then use your memory and look for hints in what you have already seen.The bad part of it is that the game is painfully and heartbreakingly short. 4 hours of gameplay is the best you can get from it, and it generally looks more like an exercise in game building - like, "look what we could do with the engine". I was feeling like the developers had initially planned something bigger and more complicated but circumstances forced them to cut their ambitions short. Small amount of gameplay time is in part based upon the lack of real content. The protagonist has come to the area for investigation but in fact he hardly investigates anything. When he actually does, the solution is often ridiculously simple, as if the game creators didn't want to bother their players with too much of intellectual business. It becomes more and more obvious as you progress towards the end of the game, and it often feels like the developers were getting tired of their product and were trying to get it finished as soon as possible.You will like it if you are fond of walking meditatively around an area and exploring. For a couple of hours you will be living in a beautiful place with a touch of weird mystery about it.You might also like it if you prefer visual novels and if you don't mind composing a story out of bits and pieces instead of following a predefined storyline.If you want to feel like a detective who tries to solve a number of challenging cases, you will probably be disappointed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Unfortunately, this game falls under that category of "games that can't decide what they want to be."As a lot of people have already said, this game has great atmosphere and visually stunning. I grew up in a small town with crumbling buildings like Red Creek Valley, so I had a heavy dose of nostalgia going for me the entire time I was playing.The way you investigating "crime scenes" was also what appealed to me about this game. It's about as close to experiencing Sherlock Holmes's "mind palace" as I've gotten in a game. This is where I'm going to get into spoilers. The first issue comes up when you're walking through the forest and suddenly you come across these beacons, and you have to find each of the beacons to unlock another piece of the puzzle of "what happened to Ethan?" Once you find all the beacons, however, you're launched into this science-fiction vision of space, which is (again) very visually captivating, but suddenly I've lost track of whether I'm in a detective game or if the game is starting to suggest that aliens are responsible for Ethan Carter's disappearance. There's also a "unlocked" scene that places you underwater, and you're looking up at this Cthulhu-like creature, as well as a sequence that places you in a mine shaft with a zombie who instantly kills you if his lantern shines on you. For both of these sequences, I found myself saying "Okay, is this Lovecraftian? Zombie? I don't care what it is, this game just needs to decide what it wants to be instead of throwing every genre at me."The other thing is that, unless you're a completionist and absolutely want to see the "final ending," you don't actually have to go through all of these sequences. You can still solve the mystery of Ethan Carter's death without solving all of the other puzzles. "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" came out in the aftermath of "Amnesia: The Dark Descent," and it very much feels like it's trying to be a lighter version of that game. There's that same Lovecraftian feel, as well as the feeling of hopelessness because--unlike so many first-person games--both Amnesia and Ethan Carter don't give you a weapon. But unlike Amnesia, there's barely any real threat to you in Ethan Carter. It's basically like reading an interactive book--the reader might be scared by it, and it may even be powerful enough to effect how he lives his life, but ultimately it can't harm him.All of this being said, there are a lot of good gameplay elements in this game that could provide the building blocks for an amazing game in the future, if put into the right hands. As said above, the way you investigate crime scenes in this game was very interesting and the only other game I can think of where I've seen something like it is the "Batman: Arkham" series. The replay value, however, is very poor, if it exists at all. In the two years since I've played this game, I've never had a moment where I've thought "You know, I should reinstall The Vanishing of Ethan Carter so I can play it again."If you're still not convinced that you're better off spending your money on something else, then at least wait until the game goes on sale. For one, the game isn't that long--you can probably beat it in a day if you have nothing else to do. That alone makes the $20 price tag seem ridiculous. If you must have Ethan Carter, wait for it to go on sale. If you pay anything more than $5.99 for it, you're getting ripped off.

												Pros:+ Amazing graphics, the best I've seen in any game -- Ever.+ Intriguing story.+ Fun, and non-frustrating puzzles.+ Like nothing you've ever played before. A breath of fresh air.Cons:- 95% of the world has absolutely 0 interactivity. The world is amazingly and jaw-droppingly beautiful but since there's almost nothing to discover, you end up just running at full speed through it.Neither Pro nor Con:~ The game is 4-5 hours long. That can be good or bad depending on what you're looking for in a game. I thought it could have been just slightly longer, maybe one more puzzle area. But overall, I was in the mood for a short game and this filled it perfectly.I purchased this for about $15 and I felt like I overpaid slightly. Anything under $12 would be a great price point to purchase this. I would recommend this if the style of the game suits you, and you pick it up on a Steam sale.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I played this for over an hour and that is time I will never get back, because as there's no manual save and despite finding a whole load of stuff and entering one of the buildings, I didn't hit a single automatic save. I want my money back, because all that this game has done for me is waste my time.Whether I do it all again now or come back later after finding a save point I'm still faced with the fact that when I've done it it probably won't be saved, and I face I don't know how many more examples of my option being do it all again or leave the program running. I should live so long.Would it have been so difficult to give us a configurable quicksave button or to automatically save whenever we achieve something? Definitely not. Clearly the programmers aren't incompetent which means they made a conscious decision to leave this huge gaping flaw in this otherwise cool looking game.It seems like pure bloodymindedness, like once they'd seen how cool and pretty it is they decided that they should also judge what the right and wrong ways to play the game are. It seems I fell on the "wrong" side, but I was just exploring. They've made this huge beautiful environment and they expect us to just rush through it to hit the savegame points before we get bored or run out of (real life) time ‚Äì How does that make sense? They haven't decided the right or wrong way to play the game ‚Äì They've shown us the wrong way to make the game. They've got my money, but hopefully it's not too late for you.Avoid.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												There is a phenomenon that when something is done too well, it fails to impress.I vacillated about whether to recommend this game, but I ultimately decided that my experience of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, unfortunately, is subject to that phenomenon. The Astronauts did a wonderful job with this game from a technical perspective, which is something everyone should support. The graphics are fantastic, the music hauntingly beautiful, and the voice-acting emotionally wrenching. That being said, the story is lacking and even the beautiful world doesn't give the game enough depth to make up for the weakness of the plot, particularly the ending. There was something about the world that just didn't draw me in--perhaps they walked the line between real and surreal so well that I was never convinced it was either. The ending is both twist and ambiguous, and I wasn't surprised by the twist and I hadn't been drawn in enough to care about the ambiguity. It just didn't leave a mark, positive or negative.After giving it some more reflection, (I‚Äôve updated this review) I can say that my problem with the plot of Ethan Carter is less a problem with this game itself (though I have given my complaints) and more likely a problem with the genre. To me exploration felt more like looking at a painting than actually stepping into a real world, and following the story felt more like checking off a list than solving a mystery.That I don't recommend The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is my statement that if I had the opportunity to do it over, I would have done something different--entered a different story in a different world if you will. But most importantly, I would have done something in a different format‚Äîlike reading a book‚Äîa clear indication of my dislike for the genre. I will be watching the future developments from The Astronauts and I do hope for another opportunity to play another game made with the same rare technical skill as this one.Bottom line: if you like walking simulators (and this is a bit more than just a walking simulator), get this one. If you are unsure of the genre, Ethan Carter is unlikely to change your mind.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												A decent concept poorly applied. A game that touts it's graphic fidelity had me worried. The only fault of graphics in this game were the god awful character models and hair that looks like they belong in Skyrim. The voice acting is rubbish and the animations at times can be extremely disgusting. The location and setting of the game are amazing. The ability to pick and choose which segment you playthrough before traversing Red Creek to the next can allude to a false sense of freedom. Red Creek is a beautiful environment to explore, despite the backtracking and absent gameplay (I mean really? Even for a game of it's nature there could have been more indepth gameplay than playing ISpy with items in the world. And then going on to set a series of events in order.) The Vanishing of Ethan Carter in it's first 30 minutes can be breathtaking and though provoking, but ultimately disappointing with a weak and lazy ending. The redux does very little to help. If a game where you walk around a beautiful environment investigating late 19th century structures is your preference, then by all means purchase it. But only on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												My girlfriend and I went through this game in one sitting, which took us about four hours. We used a walkthrough to guide us through portions of the game, so that might mean we lost an hour or two - but I don't feel that these additional hours would have been well spent. The biggest mistake this game makes is giving you repetitive searching and fetching tasks, some of which are just overly tedious and out of place in a game that is so focused on telling a story. I don't want to search for a little bloody rock hidden behind high leaves of grass to advance the plot or wander through a maze looking for five identical corpses so I can open a cryptic puzzle. No, this puzzling and combing of the vast landscape this game has to offer was not fun at all. The developers seem not to understand how to create gameplay that engages instead of distracting from the story. In a game that exists primarily to tell that story, I would actually expect less involved gameplay, so if I (as a "core" gamer of many genres) am faced with an attempt to challenge my gaming skills, I want this challenge to be fun and the opposite of tedious and grinding, but the latter is what this game offers and not much else besides the story.So is the STORY any good? Without spoiling anything, I have to say my girlfriend (who cares deeply about well-written stories) and I were both surprised at how it ended, but that ending made the whole endavour kind of pointless and just threw up more questions than answers. It's basically just a story of supernatural powers and multiple murders; you use the former to solve the latter nine times throughout this game, piecing together what happened to this Ethan Carter boy. But the end result just seems to invalidate it all and makes the supernatural aspect, which I highly disliked from the start, even more ambiguous.Dammit, if you write a story for a game soley to tell that story, then please make it a GOOD one that I can actually grasp and follow, and that is BELIEVABLE most of all! And if you start your game off saying "this game does not hold your hand" (which is rare these days and usually a good thing!), then make sure I understand how to play it because when I spend the first fifteen minutes wandering around aimlessly and have to consult a walkthrough to understand the mechanics, you've done something wrong by game design standards.I had heard only good things about this game and while I don't want to say that I regret the 10 bucks I paid for it on sale, I do wish that all the positive press and personal recommendations had actually held true in the end. I fail to see how so many people love the game when there is not much here that would make it that great.Pros:- well utilized Unreal Engine 3 with very convincing architecture and landscape- free roaming "open world" gameplay makes for great immersion- good music and convincing voice actingCons:- occasional stutters while otherwise perfectly fluid- puzzles are rarely easily apparent and require lots of searching/trial and error- story itself is not very good (personal preference) and illogical at times- this game is more of an artistic showcase than a well presented storyBuy if you liked Dear Esther and other more artsy, mysterious games that move away from traditional routes. Be prepared to do some tedious *very much traditional* puzzling and searching. Keep a guide handy to enjoy more of the actual story. Go in with low expectations.

												This game is beautifull, environment, characters, cutscenes, everything!Can't believe how flawless this game looks and sadley enough, that's the only thing the game has going for it.The gameplay is almost non existent. You play as a detective solving a case, which sounds fun, but really isn't.It took me 5 hours to beat the game, which isn't much but I don't mind since the game is so cheap, BUT:this includes 1 hour of bumping into invisible walls. 3 hours of hiking to find clues, putting back items orwalking across the entire map because you forgot something (they couldn't bother giving the player a simple quick travel method).And the remaining 1 hour is gameplay, but this isn't even fun since the actual gameplay and puzzles are very easy when you understand the mechanics of the game. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												It was visually stunning, but to me it felt like this game didn't know what it wanted to be. Even when the mystery started unraveling and I thought it could have an interesting plot, or that I was about to do something fun and interesting, the game took it away from me and gave an unsurprising, boring, safe ending. A lot of work for not a lot of payoff.Gameplay wise, the puzzles are far too simple, but if you miss one part you'll spend ages trying to figure out what went wrong. Skipped or didn't notice a puzzle? You find out at the end you'll need to walk all the way back and solve it. I had no idea there was going to be a horror maze in the middle that was required to see a cutscene that was irrelevant to the end of the game.I liked Dear Esther and Gone Home (similar in that they're creepy, long, lonely walks through a pretty environment), but wasn't a big fan of this. In theory, it's really cool. But in practice... maybe watch someone play it online?

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												This game is 90% story, 10% puzzle and atmospheric. The atmosphere is done very very well, and the story is engaging and entertaining, and does a great job of making the puzzles part of the story.  There are definitely parts where I slowed down and just appreciated the music and well-made scenery and lighting.  **From here I state my dislikes, which may be spoilers if you are going to play the game**  But I can say that the ending to the game made the rest of it not worth it. It's incongruent and feels very rushed. It's not a twist or exciting, it just feels like they couldn't come up with a proper ending to the game.  Classic noir, and that's why most of those movies don't hold up.  The good ones were good because they didn't follow this silly formula.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Really didn't find this one very enjoyable. Perhaps it would have hurt the narrative device of the game mechanic, but I really feel like this game needed a tutorial. The mechanisms for triggering exposition was just not clear enough for me. A little bit of nudging would have been really nice. Wonderful visually, and a really great mechanic for story telling, but overall just seemed empty for such a lush environment. The narrative moments are few and far between, but comprise the ENTIRE game. Aside from the...what...10 moments of plot, the entire game is walking down paths that do not serve the plot or illuminate much of anything going on. And I do get tired of story telling that keeps me wondering, wondering, wondering what could possibly be going on!!? only to find in the end that ....oh.... it was that... the whole time.... cute....Great as a study of plot delivery in games. Not much fun as an experience for a player.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Oh sweet lord. How do I begin? This game was fantastic. I didn't want this game to end. I binge played it in two nights,  This game was fantastic. I know I already said that but it needed to be stated again. I waited till this game was on sale, but I would happily pay full price for this game, now that I have played it. The game has a very meloncholy and mysterious air to it. The challenges faced in the game are difficult, but fun and interesting. The main character has an amazing voice. Not to mention the graphics. Wow. The graphics on this game are astounding. Simply lovely. I spent ten minutes just staring at the sunset on the lake. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who loves challenges, puzzles, and mysteries. *SEMI-SPOILERS* /Some might claim the ending is confusing, but for those that pay attention and gather the full details into their thoughts, it makes perfect sense. To be honest I predicted the ending, but that didn't make it any less good!/ I want a sequel to this game more than I want world peace. I would sacrifice my first born son in order to have a sequel, but I understand if that isn't possible. In my opinion I felt the game was somewhat short, but when I take into account how fast I solve puzzles, how interested I was in the story, and what the storyline generally consisted of, the amount of time it takes is more than appropriate. Fun 5/5, Graphics 5/5, Maturity 4/5, Play again 5/5. Worth the price: Yes

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												This game is hands down amazing. I played for four hours, but it had the intensity of 8. The story grips you, the mechanics flow, the visuals stun you and the audio makes your hands stand on end in dread or in awe... Okay, perhaps slighty exaggerated, but whatever, it's awesome!This game does come with some cons though.- It's very short. If I hadn't gotten this on 50% sale, I'd been dissapointed - though a good 9 seems to be a fair price to me.- The ending is a plot twist, mostly because of how cliche it is. I didn't like it at all, and I'd definitely like to rant about it, but that would spoil it. It drew similarities to a Twillight plot device, along with plot devices used by all sorts of rookie storytellers, let's put it like that. Luckily, this 'end' lasts about 5 minutes tops, so it's not great loss. Note: The end does make sense though, and does tie all the loose ends together - and even then I'd still think it better had the loose ends not been tied up.- In the beginning, it said it wouldn't hold my hands, so I thought the game would be difficult. It wasn't. It wasn't at all. At least not to me. I see others disagreeing with me, saying you 'might miss something', and granted, I didn't get 100% of all achievements... But I don't see where they're coming from. Then again, I love mystery games and PoC games, so that might be why.I can't think of any other con, so yea. It rocked. Big time. =)

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												The atmosphere is great and the visual design is amongst the best I've seen, although this is not enough to carry this otherwise underwhelming game. You're thrown in the woods and left to figure stuff out by yourself. In principle this is great, except that the game still has you on a leash. An invisible leash, which translates into you to randomly go to places in the hope of triggering some progression. The little snippets of story you uncover are nice, and the first section of the game is consequently strong, yet falls quickly into a lull when you arrive to the main storyline which pretends to be deeper and more complex than it actually is, using the unreliable narrator scope and flashbacks to convey a very superficial story. Furthermore it makes no sense internally, how the first half of the game ties in with the latter. Wrapped up with underwhelming and repetitive gameplay, the game is an overall lackluster. As mentioned, you are to walk around the map looking for items and then place them in the correct spot. There are some guessing games in which you reconstruct the chronology of an event, and there is a horribly designed maze game. Story games can be amazing, and I'm amongst the ones who enjoyed the likes of Dear Esther and Gone Home. This game fails horribly in even being close to a decent narrative game.That being said, the visual design is top notch and the atmosphere is great. The map is well designed, interesting, and the landscape is pleasing. The music contributes greatly to the game, and gives it a somewhat eerie feel. Unfortunately the poor storyline drags the atmosphere down around the second part of the game. Altogether, I'm left feeling very unimpressed by this game.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												There is a phenomenon that when something is done too well, it fails to impress.I vacillated about whether to recommend this game, but I ultimately decided that my experience of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, unfortunately, is subject to that phenomenon. The Astronauts did a wonderful job with this game from a technical perspective, which is something everyone should support. The graphics are fantastic, the music hauntingly beautiful, and the voice-acting emotionally wrenching. That being said, the story is lacking and even the beautiful world doesn't give the game enough depth to make up for the weakness of the plot, particularly the ending. There was something about the world that just didn't draw me in--perhaps they walked the line between real and surreal so well that I was never convinced it was either. The ending is both twist and ambiguous, and I wasn't surprised by the twist and I hadn't been drawn in enough to care about the ambiguity. It just didn't leave a mark, positive or negative.After giving it some more reflection, (I‚Äôve updated this review) I can say that my problem with the plot of Ethan Carter is less a problem with this game itself (though I have given my complaints) and more likely a problem with the genre. To me exploration felt more like looking at a painting than actually stepping into a real world, and following the story felt more like checking off a list than solving a mystery.That I don't recommend The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is my statement that if I had the opportunity to do it over, I would have done something different--entered a different story in a different world if you will. But most importantly, I would have done something in a different format‚Äîlike reading a book‚Äîa clear indication of my dislike for the genre. I will be watching the future developments from The Astronauts and I do hope for another opportunity to play another game made with the same rare technical skill as this one.Bottom line: if you like walking simulators (and this is a bit more than just a walking simulator), get this one. If you are unsure of the genre, Ethan Carter is unlikely to change your mind.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Unfortunately, this game falls under that category of "games that can't decide what they want to be."As a lot of people have already said, this game has great atmosphere and visually stunning. I grew up in a small town with crumbling buildings like Red Creek Valley, so I had a heavy dose of nostalgia going for me the entire time I was playing.The way you investigating "crime scenes" was also what appealed to me about this game. It's about as close to experiencing Sherlock Holmes's "mind palace" as I've gotten in a game. This is where I'm going to get into spoilers. The first issue comes up when you're walking through the forest and suddenly you come across these beacons, and you have to find each of the beacons to unlock another piece of the puzzle of "what happened to Ethan?" Once you find all the beacons, however, you're launched into this science-fiction vision of space, which is (again) very visually captivating, but suddenly I've lost track of whether I'm in a detective game or if the game is starting to suggest that aliens are responsible for Ethan Carter's disappearance. There's also a "unlocked" scene that places you underwater, and you're looking up at this Cthulhu-like creature, as well as a sequence that places you in a mine shaft with a zombie who instantly kills you if his lantern shines on you. For both of these sequences, I found myself saying "Okay, is this Lovecraftian? Zombie? I don't care what it is, this game just needs to decide what it wants to be instead of throwing every genre at me."The other thing is that, unless you're a completionist and absolutely want to see the "final ending," you don't actually have to go through all of these sequences. You can still solve the mystery of Ethan Carter's death without solving all of the other puzzles. "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" came out in the aftermath of "Amnesia: The Dark Descent," and it very much feels like it's trying to be a lighter version of that game. There's that same Lovecraftian feel, as well as the feeling of hopelessness because--unlike so many first-person games--both Amnesia and Ethan Carter don't give you a weapon. But unlike Amnesia, there's barely any real threat to you in Ethan Carter. It's basically like reading an interactive book--the reader might be scared by it, and it may even be powerful enough to effect how he lives his life, but ultimately it can't harm him.All of this being said, there are a lot of good gameplay elements in this game that could provide the building blocks for an amazing game in the future, if put into the right hands. As said above, the way you investigate crime scenes in this game was very interesting and the only other game I can think of where I've seen something like it is the "Batman: Arkham" series. The replay value, however, is very poor, if it exists at all. In the two years since I've played this game, I've never had a moment where I've thought "You know, I should reinstall The Vanishing of Ethan Carter so I can play it again."If you're still not convinced that you're better off spending your money on something else, then at least wait until the game goes on sale. For one, the game isn't that long--you can probably beat it in a day if you have nothing else to do. That alone makes the $20 price tag seem ridiculous. If you must have Ethan Carter, wait for it to go on sale. If you pay anything more than $5.99 for it, you're getting ripped off.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is decent if rather short indie first person adventure/mystery game. I played through the Redux version, so I have minimal playtime listed for the base game. The redux version is simply a remake of the original game in Unreal Engine 4 with improved graphics and few minor gameplay tweaks.The graphics are definitely the highlight here. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter has some of the most impressive nature scenes ever seen in a game. It's also a very atmospheric and immersive experience with pretty minimal handholding.Unfortunately the gameplay is somewhat disappointing. While the core mechanic of reconstructing murders by finding and ordering the clues is interesting enough, the game could have taken this much further. As it is, almost all the puzzles are on the simple side and way too much of your playtime is spent hunting for the puzzles themselves and any clues you may have missed.Overall, the Vanishing of Ethan Carter felt more like an impressive tech demo than a full game. I'd still recommend it, but only during a sale.The good:- Extremely beautiful natural environments- Atmospheric and immersive- Reconstructing the murders is an interesting mechanic, even if the game should have done much more with thisThe bad:- Quite short- Most puzzles are pretty simple- Too much aimless wandering looking for both clues and the puzzles themselves- The story is not that good

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												This is a game with a captivating story that is fun to play when you have a guide. The reason I say with a guide is that this game literally does not provide any help whatsoever on what to do in this world. There is no map (except at the end! Lol!), no tutorial, no help/hint system,  no indicator arrows, etc. The map is truly open and you can go in any direction you want. The voiceover is used only for the story and provides no help on what to do next. The scenery and music is beautiful. I enjoyed walking around this world and unraveling the story. It really does have a nice atmosphere to it. I considered only one part of the game scary. The rest of it I considered light and mysterious (although it tries to be dark, but how can you be scared/dark in such beautiful surroundings! :) ).I actually spent 6.4 hours (6.2 redux and 0.2 original) on this game in total, but it is not reflected in my stats because I played the redux version for the majority of the time. I found it better than the original in its graphics and save system. Also, this 6.4 hours was me running around the world enjoying the scenery and not knowing exactly what to do (I tried not to use the guide as much as possible). The actual game time is around 4 hours including getting all the achievements.

IF you like narrative experience, various puzzles, and is okay with finding stuff (swear to god I could never find somethings without looking it up) this game is alright.  a 6/10.

Game is not hard but you must not rush it (like I did in the first place) or you risk missing some useful informations including puzzels needed to finish the game.Pro: - amazing graphics- amazing atmosphere- the narrator's voice fits the whole game perfectly- good story with a mind blowing endingCons:- no option to save- I play at Medium to High graphics with constant 50+ fps but sometimes when the game loads it just freezes for 1-2 seconds and that is incredibly annoying- 2 achievements are quite hard to get: "Unfinished stories" and "The curse of the sea-thing" For the first one you must be extremely lucky to find certain items to accomplish it and I needed to google it in order to complete this one. As for  the "Sea Thing", well, I must be honest I've never been so frightened in my life. I played Outlast, Slender The Arrival, Amnesia, FEAR 2, and I can swear i've never been so panicked in a game.All in all, I highly recommend this game, not only for detective-type persons, but also for those who just want to enjoy a very polished world with the best atmosphere ever.(sorry for bad english)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												It's been a year since I first played this game and I am still in love with it. Unlike any other game, this stunningly unique piece of art will have you in awe. Beautiful graphics, simple controls, a tense atmosphere and, most importantly, an emotionally and psychologically engulfing story -- absolutely worth your time. Goosebump guarantee!And without spoiling too much, I would like to have a quick word with those of you who claim that the ending makes "any analysis of lines of dialogue, narrative, and story telling null and void": You obviously don't understand much about human psychology. Everything you experienced in the course of the story does matter. It is a display of human relationships and emotions, of pain and abuse, of how a child feels under certain circumstances within the boundaries of their family and expresses their feelings and finds a way to vent in order to escape said pain. Ultimately, the tragedy unfolding before your eyes explains everything you saw, heard and felt prior during the course of the story. The mystery part is just a nice bonus to it all. If you aren't capable of understanding nor feeling that, then you must be quite an unempathic human being and this game is not meant for you.

number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Kind of a "Blair Witch Project" thing. Atmosphere, horror, a few jump scares. Very beautiful world (Unreal Engine 4) with nothing to do in it. Shockingly low on content and gameplay elements. Very short too. Background story is a crude horror/mystery tale about a family possessed by a ghost and killing each other, largely told through a narrator and letters strewn across the game world (lame excuse for lacking real content and interactivity).Your job is to reconstruct who killed who, and this is how it goes:You run around and come across typical adventure items (a lamp, an axe, a dead body, etc.), but you cannot interact or do anything with them. All you have to do is find all items in a certain area, which automatically prompts a flashback scene with 5 story elements and you have to guess the sequence of events, like this: (1) he picked up the axe, (2) he talked to his brother, (3) he went over to the chapel, (4) he killed his uncle, (5) he talked to his mother. That's it. Then you head to the next area, find all its items, flashback pops up..... You do this guess-the-sequence thing for the fate of each family member. That's all there is, basically."This game doesn't hold your hand."What game? At best, this is a 3D tech demo for UE, not a game. Shame on the Polish developers for charging money for a demo.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												This game has environments that look better than the average game. Nice environments make good screenshots but once this game is in motion, you'll find that the majority of those visually impressive things loose some charm with their static nature. Rocks don't tumble and you just float through things instead of them reacting to you colliding with them. The moving branches and grass are the same 2D images that have been in many other games, which look out of place next to everything else. There are two exceptions in the form of small railcars that are operated to solve two puzzles, which are nice. Personally, photo visuals don't impress me, I am always more impressed when terrain reacts in cool ways, like sand moving, mud squishing, or boards swaying when walked over. I just mention that because I would say the visuals are the major selling point. This could lead to the game becoming more and more unimpressive as time goes by. (Additional note: There are many invisible walls)Gameplay had some good ideas but shallow execution. It is a detective story, with the gameplay insert (primarily) being figuring out the chronology of events at a crime scene. This is fun and in one instance I figured it out by looking at the position of a person's feet to determine movement direction. However, the most events you ever have to order in a sequence is 6. The final one only having 4 events that need ordering. One of the crime scenes was just a straight line. Overall there are only 5 crime scenes that you investigate. Additional gameplay involves the discovery of 5 locations that open up dialog. 2 of these locations have small puzzling sequences attached to them. But there is no gameplay climax moment that leaves you with satisfaction as you transition to the end.The narrative doesn‚Äôt mesh well with the atmosphere, I feel. I guess it is supposed to be a creepy story, but you are in the bright cheery outdoors. That can be unsettling when done properly, though nothing quite sells it here. Character models, their animations, and voice acting are quite average and damper the story (I do appreciate that character are actually seen, as many of these exploring games cut out people from the equation). One sequence is super silly, which also makes it so if you didn‚Äôt see the ending coming, you‚Äôll know what it is after that. Much of your time will be quite quiet as the game takes place in a large reasonably-open valley with only a few narration triggers and pieces of paper scattered about. I am actually quite confused, or I guess unappreciative, about this large environment as it doesn‚Äôt seem to accomplish much. I timed it, and you can go 3-5 minutes of just walking down a path to get from one location to another with just light music and ambient noise to accompany you. Since the majority of the assets are just rocks and trees, there really isn‚Äôt much you can take from the environment that fills you in on the events of the past. In the underground, I thought I was actually going down an endless staircase. It seems big for the sake of being big, or it could have used more tiny things scattered about that had more significance. Overall, this game was a solid ‚Äòeh‚Äô.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Note:  This is a spoiler free review, as such you might find the review vague.  That is an unfortunate side effect of being spoiler free.Synopsis in 10 words or less:  Its Dear Esther with bad puzzles.I had high hopes for this game, and was ultimately very disappointed.Regarding the graphics:  Pretty average.  Nothing special and nothing we haven't seen before.  I give the game kudos for being very photogenic, as there are plenty of nice locations and venues for landscape screenshots.  However, since the gameplay so often has you looking at the ground or nitpicking over objects you really will begin to notice that a lot of the environmental texturing quality is inconsistent.  I also noticed that pretty much the only visual filtering they used was sunbeams during the first few minutes of the game, and during the short yet enjoyable phases when following Ethan's writings.  The rest of the time the visual effects were static or just... more sunbeams.Regarding the narrative:  Let me put it this way; the premise is not what the game really is about.  Granted, the first hour or so feels pretty good, but then things start to get... well there is a noticable drop in quality.  Its as if for the first hour they were trying to make a game based on the original premise, and in the second half of the game they suddenly scrapped it and changed writers, but JUST BARELY managed to get a coherent story out for the end.  However, it was RIDDLED with plot holes, fridge logic, and hand waves.  It feels like a series of random events happening one after another in no real coherent pattern.  I do give them points for actually finishing the story and making a (barely) coherent narrative, but its the sort of thing that sneaks up on you on the last minute or two of the game and makes you go all "well that felt pointless and empty."  Regarding pacing:  Horrible.  Level design noticably decreased in quality during the course of the game.  At first, a lot of things were close together and there was environmental abiance after triggered events, such as distant rolling thunder over the mountains and the sky becoming overcast and such.  There is also a veeery interesting story by Ethan in the beginning.  GOOD!  However, that all just goes away after the first hour.  After that first hour, you can tell the developers tried to "lengthen" things by making a lot of space you could walk around in that was utterly empty and devoid of anything, especially between locations.  Like I said, its like they lost half their staff and needed to get out a game or something.  The worst part is that the gameplay encourages you to look in every nook and cranny because if you don't you'll probably miss something.  Regarding the Gameplay:  I'll be honest, an adventure game that doesn't hold your hand is an interesting concept but ultimately all this game does is prove that it makes for a frustrating experience.  What the game did well during the first hour or so was the feeling of exploration; the valley was big and interesting, with abiance and texture.  Buuuut that came to a grinding halt since you realize pretty quickly that the game is completely linear.  There are a lot of times when it is clear what you are supposed to do but you have no idea where something is, and many objects are placed so they blend in perfectly with the scenery (hense the immense amount of time staring at the ground and walls).  The game mixed two things together which simply don't go well together; linear experience where the only way to progress is to solve the puzzle, yet the puzzle involves finding something.  Okay, but the game doesn't give you any clues to where those things could be.  In other words, most of the time you will be wondering around aimlessly, without clues, trying to find the next thing to do in the game.  Its a lot like Dear Esther gameplay wise, with some puzzles thrown in with utterly no explanation on how to do them, and (at least after the first hour) instead of a stunning visual journey it just ends up as the same dirt corridor lined with rocks and pine trees, and houses that turn out to be a lot less interesting than they could be.  Regarding the sound work:  Average.  Music was forgetable but not unpleasant.  Pretty much all the same sound bits are recycled throughout the game, there is not a lot of variety.  Most of the sound effects are within the ambiance.Regarding the Characters:  Utterly and completely forgetable.  Nobody in this entire game stood out, at all.Replayability:  None.  The game's strongest point is being exposed to it for the first time and the feeling of exploration encountered in the first hour, after that it gets dull and boring and repetitive.  After getting kicked in the gut with the narrative at the end, replaying the game would just be a painful, predictable, slow experience.Value:  I wouldn't pay more than $3 for this game, the $20 price tag is ridiculous.  All things considered, this game has virtually no content.  The only reason I have 7 hours on this game is because 2 of those hours were AFK time, and the rest of that was just walking around to every nook and crannie trying to find‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•  I'd say the actual real gameplay in this game is a little over an 1 hour, the rest of the time you will be just trying to find stuff.  So, 1 hours of real gameplay, 4 hours spent searching for‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and 2 hours of AFK time.  Not worth $20 in any sense.In summary:  The premise is not what it seems.  Everyone in this game is forgetable, everything about this game is forgetable.  Its like Dear Esther (walk through the park type game) except added in frustrating gameplay and it literally just stops drops its strongest point, the visuals and the ambiance, after the first hour.  So you might have fun for an hour, but after that hour its just a boring, frustrating game.  This game is definitely not worth $20, and if you want a similar yet much better game go play Dear Esther (its free too).

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												As a technology showcase for the Unreal engine this game does a fine job as it is exceedingly pretty and fabulously detailed even on modest hardware; but as an enjoyable narriative experience it's singularly lacking.It starts off on the wrong foot by boldly proclaiming "This game is a narrative experience that does not hold your hand." What exactly is the purpose of this? Is it a dig at other games? An attempted disclaimer against this sort of criticism? Are they not confident that the nature of the game will become readily apparent through playing it? It's up to the gamer to decide what the experience means to them, so stating "this is a narrative experience" comes across as somewhat presumptuous.Also, what's wrong with a linear narrative? That's how narratives have worked for countless ages -- you're taken through them by some other agency. Whether you're listening to a story, reading a book or watching a film, you are led through the narrative. The interactive nature of games opens up unprecedented opportunities for non-linear storytelling, but that doesn't mean there's anything wrong with the old sort.Anyway, the game. It opens up in a pretty, forested, mountainous and remote setting. Right away there are creepy traps and a gristly murder scene, which sets the scene as a sort of less-subtle Stephen King knockoff. There's an obvious puzzle - as in, something that is obviously a puzzle - and yet it became quickly obvious that solving it was optional, and that one could press ahead if one so wished.A sinking feeling that this was the narrative-delivery mechanism made me stick around to try and solve it, because I knew that I wasn't going to want to come back. One of the things you need to find is a small rock. Your unspecified spidey-sense does not help with the location of gameplay objects. The environment is filled with rocks. After a few minutes another sinking feeling that locating hard-to-find objects played a big part in this prompted me to a walkthrough, which disappointingly confirmed my suspicions on both counts. After moving the tiny rock a few yards, you then have to reassemble some fragments of a cutscene into the right order, so that the cutscene will play, something which serves no purpose other than wasting time.Not holding your hand though a narrative is one thing, but denying you that narrative until you jump through the relevant arbitrary puzzle hoops is unforgivable. A well designed puzzle is one which you feel that you *want* to solve for no reason other than to solve it. When you can see what you have to do but don't want to do it -- that is a poorly designed puzzle.The narrative segment itself was largely implausible, as those which centre around killing someone by running them over with a train tend to be.Each 'section' follows the same basic premise; there's been a horrible moider, you need to find a specific object, move it a few yards, use your spidey sense and then assemble the pieces of a cutscene. One of the sections features a completely out-of-place jump scare (which does nothing other than to push you back to the start of a maze section and destroy and immersion which you may have managed to accumulate) and then cumulates in the sort of symbol arranging pseudopuzzle that at least had the good grace to always have the same solution so that the walkthrough screenshot would solve it.The story was working towards a fairly generic sleeping-horror-must-not-be-woken kind of deal but I quite like those so stuck with it; but then at the last moment it faked out with an epically lame twist, and the credits left me feeling profoundly disenfranchised -- and that is the sole reason for my 'not recommended' review; it left me feeling like I'd wasted my time playing it.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												The concept for this game had a lot of potential, but the story was severely lacking in depth and left you feeling jipped. The main focus of the game semmed to be on the aesthetics, which was impressive. The story, however, made an attempt to be complex and interesting, but it did not quite hit that mark. In addition, the voice acting was poor to the point that it took away from the experience. I was anticipating the release of this game, but ended up being disappointed. The open-world aspect of the game is limited and all it really affords the player is potentially unfolding the story in a mismatched order, which can definitely lead to a confused individual.Overall, while this game is very pleasing to the eye, it had a restrictive and convoluted flow that, for the most part, did not allow for the gamer to use the current scene at hand to determine where to go next. Instead, you have to wander around, hopefully finding all of the places in the "open-world" map.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ - "Average at best, Id give it a miss" PROS:- Visually stunning, the game is beautiful. The textures are incredibly detailed and realistic and theres a atmosphere similar to that from Naughty Dog's 'The Last of Us'.- Room changing and Maze puzzle. This game has two terrific puzzles which whilst not difficult, worked brilliantly. The latter provides a cheeky little scare also.-Soundtrack completely sets the tone and reflects on the areas you visit and helps with immersion.CONS:- Puzzles, I only mentioned two cause in my opinion they were the only ones. For a game heavily labelled with the genres 'Mystery' and 'Detective' its completely unjustified. The detective elements are shallow as hell, they're almost insulting. At first with the traps I thought the game had pulled me into another world but I soon realised it simply tells you where to go with images not hard to work out. When you start the game it tells you, 'We will not hold your hand'..this is a lie. Whilst they are no checkpoints or mission icons the mystery elements give you everything you need without allowing you to solve a thing. There could have been real clues to make you think and lead you to the next area but instead you're told by a series of words and in some cases you line them up using the camera.- Story, this just about makes a Con cause reflecting back I did actually want to know what was going on, but do I even now? Not really, its so vague and difficult to understand not because its complicated but because its such a daft premise and it has a terrible ending.- Choose the Order of the events..okay so this is the games main mechanic. What happens if you guess incorrectly? Nothing. You try again. In some cases its insultingly easy and the stances or animations are nothing, they feel like they're put in just to make up time and gameplay. Frogwares recent Sherlock Holmes instalment 'Crimes and Punishments' has this mechanic however it only utilises it on 3 occasions during the game and its done better. That game is made out of repercussions of decisions, mini game puzzles, interrogation and real detective elements.- You feel like you achieve nothing, I didn't feel in control of anything as a detective, its more of a walking simulator like Dear Ester and more importantly like reading a book. Theres nothing wrong with that other than its not what is says on the tin.- ¬£14.99 for 4 hours of gameplay, no thanks. Thankfully I paid ¬£3 and thats all its worth I'm afraid.VERDICT?Its important that I inform you I planned on giving this a recommendation when I set out with this review, for the first time I have change my mind whilst writing. Thats how on the fence I was, however on reflection this game has a real lack of substance and in my opinion lies about its detective elements and about offering you a difficult thought provoking experience without much guidance. I was totally disappointed with this game.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												This game has as much "game play" and "depth" as a a typical graphics benchmark, such as "Heaven Benchmark". It looks pretty..., but I am afraid that it is as far as it goes from what I've been able to play.The game world is literally dead. There are no NPCs, animals, or anything to interact with. Nothing lives in that word. But you'll get lots of trees. Wonderful trees. Beautiful trees. And water. Trees and gorgeous scenery. If that's what you like and expect from GOOD GAME ...And you run around for hours and literally nothing happens. The story/plot is cringe-worthy, it seems to be a very stereotypical ghost/paranormal story. All that would be acceptable if the game would actually be motivating, if something, ANYTHING would happen. But it doesn't. Instead you wander around and encounter relatively mindless and "forced" seeming puzzles interwoven with that stereotypical ghost story.  But sorry, I have absolutelly no motivation to continue ... :((

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Can't say it's worth playing for anything than the beautiful visuals, which is a shame really. I thought this game had massive potential but it only took me 3 hours to get 100% achievements with no reason to play again, and the time I spent with it was pretty mediocre. The story was drab - which is vitally important for these kinds of games. The puzzles were extremely simplistic in a 'find the hidden object' kind of way. I'm honestly kind of baffled how this has such a high score.I grabbed it in a recent sale for a decent price so I don't feel cheated but I don't think it's a must play title or anything. Definitely not worth full price. Maybe $5 on sale. It's better than Dear Esther at least, but that's not saying much.If you want a good 'walking simulator' then really you should just play The Stanley Parable and skip this.Anyway this game seems designed for a very particular kind of person and mindset and apparently I'm not that person.

Posted: July 25, 2016
												If you had told me this game was anything other than a graphics showcase or a demo I would not have believed you. After beating the game, I just thought I had completed the intro and there was much more to come. But no, 1 hour and 20 minutes of gameplay and it was over. With a good speed run the game could easily be done in under an hour.The game is really beautiful and I would definitely call it unique, even had some pretty cool moments but for the lack of gameplay overall it gets pretty poor negative review from me. I bought this for 80% off during a sale and I still don't feel like I got my money's worth. I think you're just expected to stumble around and do things slowly and out of order, but even then I can't imagine getting any more than 4 hours out of this.On the bright side, it's probably one of the fastest and easiest games to get a perfect game for achievements with :p I'm not really sure if that's a good thing, but there it is.
